description:
Their Pho quality is very consistent. It's light and with clear broth. It tastes healthy and not like other places just put MSG.

Both of their chicken Pho and Beef Pho are nice and don't forget to get their Imperial Rolls.

The Shrimp salad is one of my favorites!
author: Julie L.

description:
This is a clean restaurant with average pho (I feel like the best pho places are usually really dirty ones with a number like Pho 66 or something). Came here after work with some coworkers and we all got the pho. The broth is average and small in size compared to most pho places and slightly more expensive. The broth is fragrant but lighter in flavor.

I think this would be a good place to introduce a newbie to pho, but definitely isn't super authentic. The restaurant feels a bit cramped as it is small with barely room to walk through. It does seem clean with good service, however, so I give it that!

Will most likely be back given the convenient location.
author: Michele L.

description:
Came here for lunch after Dude's appointment at UCSF Divisadero.  It wasn't too busy yet so we got a table in the back and ordered #9 which was the five spice grilled chicken over rice and I had the #11 the bun with grilled pork and meatball with vermicelli.  

The five spice chicken was flavorful and the bun was A-ok, nothing spectacular and the portions were small for the price.  Perhaps the noodle soups are better.  Next time, if it's a cold day, we'll try the soups!
author: Karen W.

description: one of our fav pho spots. they have the fresh noodles and really good broth. I do wish they put more noodles in the bowl since it seems that I'm out of noodles after 3 bites.  parking is hard and lunch time rush requires a long wait. but come off hours and try the pho!
author: Jax H.

description: Good place for a quick bite, but if you're going for lunch, be prepared to wait. Came here for lunch during a days-long visit to UCSF Divisidero. A nurse at UCSF recommended the place and said that she and coworkers eat there all the time. We seated at a window table about 20 mins after putting our name on the list, which is fair as there seemed to be a lot of employees from UCSF waiting for lunch as well. The pho was pretty good and piping hot. Broth was ok, kinda light but had pretty good flavor. My dad ordered the chicken vermicelli and it was delightfully tasty as well, although he ordered chicken, and they gave him beef. The restaurant was clean and the staff was friendly.
author: Jessica S.

description: Small restaurant specializing in pho.  Very disappointed.  Bland broth and no traditional accompaniments offered (chili basil bean sprouts etc).   I am always on the hunt for a good pho spot.  This is not it.
author: Chris T.

description: I generally prefer southern Vietnamese-style pho, but this is an exception! The broth is amazing and authentic, perfect for a cold day or a day when you are burdened with a cold. I also love their Thai iced tea and the waiting staff are always so nice and welcoming.
author: Theresa Thao N.

description:
I had a doctor's appointment nearby so it was convenient to go there for lunch afterwards.

I can see how this place is popular as it's literally across the street from Mt Zion hospital, people in scrubs are there for lunch or order takeout.

I ordered a regular size Ph gà đc bit (chicken rice noodle soup special free range chicken and rare eye of round steak). It had chicken broth, came with flat rice noodles instead of the clear mung bean noodles, chicken was slices of dark meat and beef was smaller sized sliced round steak. It was the perfect portion for me since I don't eat that much but I can see how people would find the portions small. It was a basic bowl of pho for the area.

Service is pretty quick - after you finish your meal, pay up in front.
author: Nette T.

description:
HEALTH HAZARD ALERT! 
This restaurant holds to go orders on the floor, food should be 2 feet above the ground.
(See picture)
author: Marat V.

description: Pretty mediocre food and $10 for a very  small glass of zinfandel. Really? I should have noticed the 81 for the health scorecard.
author: Leslie C.

description: Very skimpy and thin slices of chicken. No flavor and not worth the price or the wait. Very disappointing.
author: Muey S.

description:
I've passed by this place a couple of times and always said to myself I'd try this place out sometime.

Well, sometime arrived and I was pleasantly surprised.

Food
Delicious! Simple yet extremely tasty and hits the spot, really feels like a home cooked meal

Service
Great, very friendly, and great table service

Decor
The place feels very minimalist, it's not crowded, or loud, and you can just enjoy a nice meal.

Highly recommended! This place is great for lunch! It is now one of my favorite Pho shops in the city, glad I finally decided to drop in.

FYI, the pho served here is northern style, Pho Bac, meaning more simple and clear broth, wider rice noodles, and no bean sprouts / basil/ etc.
author: Mike L.

description:
Nice place to drop in for a quick lunch. They had plenty of seats and our food came out quickly. There is a small selection of appetizers, pho bowls, and rice and noodle plates. I got the chicken satay with rice, fresh herbs, satay sauce, and peanuts ($10). It was a nice portion for lunch and enough for me to feel full but not enough for leftovers. The satay sauce was flavorful and had a nice combination of a peanut flavor with a slightly spicy taste. I decided to ask for no herbs on my plate since otherwise they give a very large serving of mint, cilantro, and lettuce that is a little overwhelming to me (also I dislike cilantro), but other people seemed to enjoy it. 

Service was a little lacking and we had to wait quite a while to be able to get the check but they were busy for lunch.
author: Amy C.

description: Authentic and clean Vietnamese food. If you're either looking to try Vietnamese food for the first one or eat it regularly this place is amazing. They serve northern Vietnamese pho which means they're softer noodles made from chicken broth instead of beef broth.
author: Thomas C.

description:
My Father's Kitchen is right beneath the building that I work in, so this restaurant is my regular lunch spot. The Chicken Pho here is not something you can compare with Turtle Tower but it is actually decent enough for me to eat it over and over again. Price? $9 for a small bowl and $10 for a large. They have no problem with me substituting my chicken for all dark meat which I really appreciate. Why 4 stars? Well, I wish the portion size were bigger... =T 

Overall, great restaurant for a quick warm bite. Make sure to get there before lunch hour (12pm) because it gets packed with all Kaiser and UCSF employees.
author: Annie Y.

description:
This place probably won't blow your socks off, but the food is quick, simple, and pretty tasty.

I ordered the chicken satay for takeout, which came out to $10. It's definitely not a lot of food for the price, maybe just like a small chicken breast's worth of meat, and handful of herbs, and a large scoop of rice, but the flavor is good. The chicken has a nice grilled flavor, and the satay sauce is creamy, peanuty, and really good. I just wish there was more of this peanut sauce than the small cup they give you so I could pour it over my rice, which was out of proportion to the amount of meat that came with the meal.

Overall, the food is solid but not spectacular. The major issue here is the small portions. If you're looking for a light lunch to just keep you fueled until dinner, this place will probably do the trick.
author: Eric Y.

description:
The food was just okay and service was just ok. Maybe because I had better Vietnamese food  before.
I only went there because it's right front of my moms hospital Ucsf .My mom liked the food so we might go there again after her treatment. Little pricey but what do you expect, it's San Francisco .
author: Miok C.

description:
I liked this place a lot at first, but then they served me a shrimp spring roll instead of vegetarian, and I'm allergic to shellfish. When I told my waitress they brought me a veggie spring roll, and then still charged me for it at the end. I'm shocked that they would mess up such a simple order when vegetarian was the first word out of my mouth, and I explained I'm allergic but they didn't comp the item. I will absolutely never go here again and recommend anyone with food sensitivities stay away.

I'll be feeling like crap for the next couple days because of this.
author: Sarah K.

description: I had a scrumptious lunch here. Chicken Satay #10. Totally above ordinary, delicious chicken and a crazy Satay sauce that seemed to be mixed with coconut milk. Highly recommend this dish - almost ordered a second one.
author: Lynn R.

description:
Truth be told, I would have never noticed this place had I not had a series of appointments at Kaiser Permanente around the corner on Geary Street. I kept looking over wondering if their Vietnamese food was any good since it didn't look like the ramshackle small businesses in Little Saigon. It has a more contemporary feel that fits more suitably into Lower Pac Heights and the types of diners who end up here for lunch. The cleanly presented menu here is on the modest side - papaya salad, imperial and spring rolls, five pho bowls, a couple of rice plates, and a couple of noodle vermicelli dishes (photo: http://bit.ly/2sa76sb).

I decided to go for the $11 Large Bowl of Pho Bo Dac Biet, the combination beef rice noodle special with eye of round and brisket (photo: http://bit.ly/2sasTAj), because it's the bowl closest in spirit to menudo, my favorite Mexican soup. I wish I could say how rich and satisfying it was given the family recipes they appeared to be using, but unfortunately it was rather bland and lacking the discernible flavor profile I was hoping to find. I will say that the staff was friendly and reasonably serviceable, although they tended to linger with talkative regulars at their tables at the expense of the rest of us. No pho for me here.

FOOD - 3 stars...sadly an unmemorable bowl despite having all the ingredients I would expect
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...more coffee shop than Little Saigon bistro
SERVICE - 3 stars...friendly but should be more atttentive to all their customers
TOTAL - 3 stars...not a pho I need to run back for
author: Ed U.

description: First time here this evening. Very pleased! Quaint little spot, friendly staff, quick service, and my pho was outstanding! Would definitely recommend!
author: Coleman T.

description: Had chicken Pho, broth & noodles great, wish I could say the same about the chicken. Had several overcooked or tough pieces that also needed the fat trimmed. That was disappointing & annoying too. Service there is friendly & prompt. I'm glad I finally stepped in and would probably go again.
author: Henry K.

description: I came here to eat lunch. There was a four top open but since I'm in a wheelchair they would not sit me there. They wanted me to wait until another table opened up that was more convenient for them. How frustrating! I left after 20 minutes of waiting while another table sat empty.
author: Frances S.

description: My first experience was via Caviar delivery. I had a chicken pho ($10) and it was delicious. You can tell they used organic chicken by the clean flavor and I really enjoyed the broth. They don't serve egg noodles, but they have the thick rice noodles. On another Caviar delivery, I ordered a satay chicken ($10), and that was even more delicious. Chicken was boneless, soft and perfectly seasoned by the satay sauce, which is kind of like a curry sauce. On my 3rd try, I came in for five spice chicken, and it was ok. The cafe sua da was also ok too. Service was kind and helpful, even boxing up my leftovers. I will be back for pho and satay chicken!
author: Thomas L.

description:
My friends and I have lovingly dubbed this cozy little spot: "The crack house". 
A tiny bustling place that serves deliciously addictive Northern Vietnamese comfort food.

The 1 page menu is simple and only has about 5 dishes- all equally enticing, depending on your mood and weather. 

You MUST start with the #3 crispy imperial spring rolls. (They do half orders as well- pictured) Make sure to dip them in the fish sauce and Sriracha for added flavor. But watch out, they squirt out hot oil that will blister the inside of your mouth. (Yes, it's worth it and you get the hang of it after a few incidents)

Next, you have to decide between the Chicken Satay (#10 pictured) mary's grilled, boneless chicken with peanut sauce, rice, and a generous heap of greens OR the Marinated Grilled Pork (#11) with meatballs and rice vermicelli. Make sure you pour the meat and fish sauce onto the noodles. 

But if you're feeling under the weather or you happen to get one of those rare, cold foggy San Francisco days, order the BEEF pho! The small or large bowl comes with rare eye of round steak, brisket, AND flank (pictured) Add the lemon and jalapeños and slurp it to your heart's content. 

They offer beer and wine but I always get their secret recipe Thai Iced Tea or their Drip Hot or Cold Vietnamese coffee. 

Avoid the lunch rush (11:30-2) and you'll never have to wait. Sit at one of the two window tables to avoid the chair shuffle and enjoy the view.
author: Mitzi G.

description:
My Father's Kitchen stirs the same confusion as Home Cafe: 
"I went to My Father's Kitchen for lunch." ".......what?"
"I went to Home this morning." "......what?"

The pho is decent, but nothing mind-blowing; plus, it's Pac Heights pricing ($9-10 regular, $10-11 large). Yelpers have complained about the portions and while it does appear quite small, you're mainly missing a large bowl with more broth. The amount of noodles and meat isn't too far off from standard pho places, and keep in mind that not every pho restaurant can brag about free-range-chicken pho ga. 

Service is efficient, and my pho arrived before I finished scrolling through my phone distractions. The temperature was just right as well, sufficiently warm but cool enough to inhale if you are hungry. One of my gripes is the small spoon; the handle is especially short so you need to keep holding it or it'd sink into the soup. Also, you have to eat very slowly because you can't fit a large chunk of the wide rice noodles on the spoon.

My Father's Kitchen is ideal as a quick stop for a heart-warming bowl of Pho in the perpetual noodle-soup-weather of SF.
author: Edna C.

description: I've tried this place a few times before, and have usually been disappointed. I don't know why I keep wanting to give it a chance?! The place always has people, and they all look pretty satisfied, and I guess I just want to be satisfied like they look. It's the only Vietnamese place around, and phò in San Francisco is such a good fit, if it's good. I've had the phò before, and it's very underwhelming! The broth isn't very flavorful, and you don't get all the typical condiments that accompany phò. They don't even have all the typical sauces that a good phò place usually has! No hoisin sauce, chili sauce, sambal, or chili oil! This time I had the grilled chicken and fried spring rolls. The chicken portion is small, and it tasted as dry as it looked! The flavor was aiight. The rice was hard, but the spring rolls were even harder!!! The flavor was actually decent, and if it had a good crunch, all would be good, but it's like they dipped it in rice flower before frying, but over did it! It literally scratched the roof of my mouth! I just don't see why people continue to come, outside of the fact that there aren't really many good Asian food options in the neighborhood! And a lot of the folks are probably having to deal with some kind of business dealing with the surrounding hospitals. The place looks decent. The seating is shared. And the service is alright. I think I'm done giving them a chance. Just not worth the price, or the time.
author: Dezi S.

description: I'm not a hipster as I've never been to Viet Nam, so I can't call the food "authentic". How about "good"?  Yeah. "Good" works. Been here a bunch of times, mostly when I'm working at UCSF. I almost always get the pho. I try different ones. My favorite is the chicken and beef. Tasty stuff. Good broth. Really clear. Not at all fatty. The meat is quite nice and the noodles are wider than I get at other Vietnamese places. It's some tasty food when you're in a hurry or need some good comfort foot that isn't full of fat.
author: Dave C.

description:
I come here sometimes during my lunch hour to satisfy my soup craving, and it just does that! I've really only had their pho, and it's really good and flavorful once you put all the yummies in. 

But, they give you like a small bowl with like three jalapenos on it and no bean sprouts...which is odd since most of the places that I've been to usually add that in. I'm also used to adding a lot of chili oil -which they don't have. Without all the additives it doesn't really make it that flavorful.
author: Margarita O. S.

description: No! No! And no! I paid $13 dollars for this? 2 pieces of meat? Don't waste your time. They are ripping people off big time. Kind people but that's a big no for me.
author: Sophie P.

description:
This 5 star review is for their 1 dish that I often crave and keep coming back for:

#11 marinated grilled pork and meatballs served with fresh herbs, rice vermicelli, and fish sauce

I've tried this at other places, but they just don't compare to the way My Father's Kitchen prepares this dish. It's a small restaurant with limited seating so I try to make it in early before the lunch rush, as close to 11am as possible. But their service is fast and they turn over tables quickly. Stop by this little gem if you're ever in the area and try our #11.
author: Rea S.

description: Great imperial rolls, great fresh rolls, and decent pho ga. I wouldn't travel across town for it but if you are in the area, it is a tasty lunch option.
author: MJ C.

description: Good alternative if you're at UCSF Mt Zion Hospital. Lots of pho; a couple of dry vermicelli dishes. The only downside is it's salty and maybe they use msg.
author: Tracy Y.

description:
I'm very disappointed. I ordered a large beef noodle aka pho biet and it looks nothing like pho and it's such a small amount of noodle. It took me 3 bites and it is not the right noodle. I asked the cashier if it's Vietnamese restaurant or Chinese and she says is Vietnamese but I heard the cookers spoke in Cantonese. 

I have pho all my life and I know what the type of pho I eat but this one it's more like Chinese pho so plain. Not worth my money!!
author: Shiji Y.

description: Ugh! The worst service and Vietnamese Restaurant ever. What southeast Asia restaurant doesn't serve basil or sprouts with their pho? The nerve to stare me down as well, first and last time!
author: Luna T.

description: Food is simple. Nothing much special but the portion is really small. I come here for convenience instead driving to another location by myself. Sometimes it's really hard to get through the phone to order to go. They said they are busy and don't have to to pick the calls. I guess they don't want business. This is so sad to hear from them.
author: Jo Jo C.

description: Nourishing food at solid prices.  Pho is amazing.  Bun cha/vermicelli salad came with an incredible variety of tasty herbs. Looking forward to coming back.
author: Suzy F.

description:
Cleanest broth flavor and quality ingredients.  It's the minimalist version of traditional pho. It doesn't come with all the basil and bean sprouts, but I'm ok with it.  
My other favorite dish is their Spring rolls.. their home made peanut sauce is super creamy and flavorful. It actually tastes like peanuts!
author: N. C.

description: We ordered a chicken and beef pho and an all beef pho. Good prices and small portions. The broth isn't too greasy. No hoisin sauce. Don't order a regular size because you will leave hungry. They offer flat noodles. Overall the taste is good and fresh. But I'm not sure I'll return unless I just happen to be in the area. I prefer the more greasy and I guess junky type pho.
author: Guisela L.

description:
The food was quite tasty, but hard to justify going back with LOADS of MSG used.  My vermicelli noodles came deconstructed, as is northern style.  It was a little messy and I had to use my hands.

wont be coming back.
author: Angelica C.

description:
I'm thankful for this pho place because I got out of core40 and literally was out of breath since my nose was so congested! (After a decade of living in SF, I'm still not used to these foggy summers!) 

The pho maybe sparse of trimmings, aside from some chopped green onions and cilantro, but the broth is decent. I don't have to take the bus all the way to the Inner Richmond to get my hands on a hot bowl of Vietnamese cureall. The thinly sliced beef was tender and the noodles weren't a big wad of mess. However, I dislike paying $10 for a small bowl, but what are you gonna do?! it's neighborhood pricing.

Hopefully I won't have a cold again anytime soon because $10 pho for a small bowl is a joke.
author: Janice C.

description: 6-inch strand of dark hair in my pho. Unsanitary. Left immediately.  I should have checked yelp for reviews before I went in to get a quick bite after leaving UCSF.
author: Kristine F.

description:
[Pretty solid 4.5 stars]

Directly across the street from UCSF Mt. Zion Hospital is where you will find this super cute ma n' pop restaurant. I found myself in the restaurant after seeing how packed it was inside, thinking to myself "try this place or you will regret it." They probably have a max 25 person capacity/chairs and the tables are pushed together, so don't be surprised if you find yourself sitting next to a stranger, this could be fun. 

After ordering and paying for my #7 Noodle Soup, I waited just under 10 minutes, until I received my food. In my take-out bag I found the broth separate from the rice noodles, onions and meat. They also provide a small container with a lemon, a few slices of jalapeños and Sriracha. One would think the portions are small, but after finishing a  "small" I feel more than content, full. 

5 stars for good customer service during the busiest time of the day, lunch time. 
5 stars for the Broth.
5 stars for the meat, nice n' red and raw.
-.5 for the egg noodles being super soggy after mixing it into the broth. I couldn't even twirl them onto the fork without the noodles breaking and they just turned into mush. 

Personally, I prefer vermicelli noodles in my PHO because they don't get as soggy as the rice noodles. Because the broth was so dang good, it didn't matter that the noodles we're practically mashed potatoes.

At the end of the day, I didn't encounter any problems before, during or after my visit and my belly is full of happiness!
author: Lene N.

description: This place is amazing and the service is great!! The food is delicious. My favorite is the chicken noodle soup, and at times I sub out the chicken for tofu. Delicious!
author: Stephany M.

description:
#38/2016

I've wanted to try this restaurant for the longest time but its proximity to UCSF and Kaiser always leads to long, weekday lines at lunch. 

The staff told us Saturday is much more sane and we came at the right time, just around noon for an early lunch. We easily snagged a table. 

By the time we left at 12:45, the restaurant was nearly full, a testament to its success.

We ordered Imperial rolls ($7.50) and despite their light color, they're perfectly crunchy and hot with tasty pork, crab, wild shrimp, mushrooms and cellophane noodle filling. 

I asked for extra lettuce & mint to wrap them up and dip in the accompanying fish sauce; they were delicious. 

My little boy & I also split the Mary's five-spice chicken rice plate ($9) and it was delicious and just right for two people when paired with a shared appetizer. 

I tried the.Vietnamese iced coffee ($3.50) and while strong and almost chocolate-y, I should've ordered the Thai iced tea instead. I liked it was brewed by cup at the table, a lesson in mindfulness as it slowly filled the glass.

The restaurant is super clean, uncluttered and inviting and they do a brisk take-out business that was in full swing even on a Saturday afternoon. 

I love the clean tastes of Vietnamese food and while the menu is quite small, each item we ordered was terrific and what we saw coming out of the kitchen for other tables looked delicious, too.

Inexpensive, tasty, clean and savory. If you haven't already discovered this gem, it's worth a bookmark or a try.
author: Jennifer O.

description: Excellent Broth with really good flavor. The noodles and the meat are both very fresh! No MSG.. favorite noodle place in the bay! :)
author: Vivian K.

description: 5 stars because it's my go to pho shop whenever I'm craving it. Outside it being my go to, not really much about this place, just a small establishment serving a small variety of Vietnamese cuisine and drinks.
author: Kafilat Y.

description: The pho was mediocre and the service was pretty lame. C'mon people! You're one of a thousand Vietnamese restaurants, set your self apart!
author: Jojo M.

description:
I came here for lunch after an appointment at Kaiser down the street. I ordered the chicken pho noodles. I would say this is not your typical pho restaurant, a bit more upscale, however with less options. The pho was okay, not outstanding. 

I would go again for the sake of convenience. I wish they had more options and authentic dishes.
author: Claire W.

description: Very friendly and welcoming atmosphere the PHO  was very tasty . I hoped the broth would have been a bet more fortified with beef bones but can't wait to return and try other options
author: Terrance G.

description: Horrible service, two groups got their pho before we even got to order, even though we got seated first. Had to ask for our waters. No offers on water refills. The group next to us got their check first when we were obviously waiting for ours prior to them. Therefore we had to go up to the counter and ask for our check. Never coming back. The pho is not the greatest either. Noodles are thick and soggy and the broth is bland. Had to ask for the sauces and mint to get brought out. Don't think this place knows a thing or two about customer service or Vietnamese food
author: Gina V.

description:
Was working at UCSF medical center for the day and wanted something hot n soupy.  The staff at UCSF that this was pretty good. Saw the reviews on yelp and thought ok no other pho paces close so ill try it.  
After eating a $10 bowl of their pho bo dac biet, i wasn't satisfied.  I'm viet, so i know what a hearty bowl is suppose to taste like and it wasn't it.  Very disappointed and noodles ate big. For American ppl, i guess it taste good but for me it was meh.
author: katelyn n.

description: Yesterday was my second visit and it was even better than the first. The food is delicious and arrives quickly. And judging by the amount of customers it's clearly a neighborhood favorite. I will definitely visit anytime I'm in the area.
author: Mai-Linh S.

description:
Being locals and it being gloomy with a drizzle of rain, My besties took me here for my birthday lunch.  We were seated right away.  We ordered the fresh spring rolls, the egg rolls and we each got a pho' bowl. It was the right amount of beef to noodles for the pho'. The spring rolls are fresh and amazing with the peanut sauce!
The establishment is cozy (just like all the establishments in the city) but modern.  It was filled up for lunch.  Service was quick and easy.
author: Remie M.

description:
Northern style pho - no hoisin sauce, bean sprouts, or basil at this place. Give it a shot though! I really liked the noodles here. The broth is light and not as flavorful or savory as the pho I'm used to but it's still tasty and comforting.

The service here is nice and the place is clean. The prices are a little high for typical pho. A large bowl was $10. We got the beef and chicken pho bowls. Both were really good and served with plenty of meat. I actually liked the chicken pho better.
author: Linda X.

description: Best pho in the neighborhood. Good service, clean, quick and always good food. Unassuming local spot but an almost weekly visit for me!
author: Alexandra H.

description: We came to this place around 2pm on a Tuesday. There were three of us and we had to wait about fifteen minutes for a table. We ordered Thai iced tea, pho tai, and vegetarian spring rolls. The iced tea was good, not the best I've had not the worst I've had. The pho was okay as well, the noodles are thicker like egg noodles and they only bring lemon wedges and jalapenos to add to the soup. The spring rolls were fairly flavorless, but the peanut sauce was delicious. The service was great, but three stars due to the overall okayness of the food. Maybe they specialize in other dishes we didn't try?
author: Kamryn K.

description:
Small space. Over priced food. Not authentic Vietnamese food.

Very disappointed, I've been working at ucsf for awhile now and I've been wanting to try it out but it wasn't what I expected. Not comforting at all
author: Jo C.

description:
Came to this place during the weekend and it was packed but we still got seated right away
Ordered the beer pho
Weird thick noodles, not the traditional pho noodles
Average amount of meat
Broth was average as well
$9-$10 for the bowl
Overall it was alright, would not visit again.
author: Michele G.

description: My husband and I are from SoCal and love our Pho spots at home. We both ordered Beef Pho ($10 for a large). The ingredients other than beef were minimal and the broth had very little flavor. The restaurant was fairly clean, but no music playing and the service was just okay. We'll try a different pho restaurant next time.
author: Anna E.

description: I'm rating this place based solely on their pho. Pho is my jam and I'm trying to hit all of the places in the city to see which ones are best. Unfortunately, My Father's Kitchen is the closest Vietnamese place to my house but does not make the top of my list. The broth is so-so. Not as flavorful as most of the other places I've tried. And for the pho tai, they use the fat, wide noodles which I don't like as much as the thinner vermicelli noodles. But even when I get their pho with the thinner noodle, the dish lacks the flavor I want. The large bowl isn't that big and they don't give you a ton of meat, but they don't skimp either. Overall this place is solid, but if you're looking for some of the best pho SF has to offer, this isn't the place.
author: Brendan B.

description: This place was a blast! I went here for lunch one day with my brother and parents. I really enjoyed the steak soup that they had to offer as it was very delicious! I think the soups that me and my brother and parents got were nicely cooked and were made good, and there wasn't anything in particular wrong about them! I think that you should really check this place out some time if you're visiting the city for some time like on vacation, as this place really does deserve 5 stars!
author: Asher D.

description: Good pho. Always a bit packed and they don't offer table sharing for individual lunch withers. Still great on a cold day and friendly service.
author: Eiman J.

description:
I normally get the food to go and call in ahead of time. If so, your food will be ready in 10-15 minutes. I find their food to be pretty good. My favorite are their spring rolls with peanut sauce. The order is large enough to make a meal. 

I will say if you are trying to eat here during the lunch break rush, well good luck. A lot of people like to go here between the lunch rush hour (12-1pm). So you may find yourself waiting for some time until you're seated. Any other time, it's fine. 

Their satay chicken rice place is really good as well as their chicken pho.
author: Ruby V.

description: I think this place is great. It can get busy - but takeout is quick. It's fairly priced and the staff is sweet. I like the food - I usually get the pho ga. I am not a pho expert but it hits the spot for me! Check the hours before you come.
author: Emma B.

description: Love the chicken pho and the number 9. They are fast and delicious and clean. Neighborhood place that is always friendly and their flavors are on point.
author: Anne S.

description:
There are way better Vietnamese restaurants in this city, but my Father's Kitchen is so convenient, fast, and gets the job done.

What keeps me coming back is their fresh shrimp or pork spring rolls with that sweet peanut butter sauce. That sweet, sweet, delicious peanut butter sauce.

Did I mention the peanut butter sauce?
author: Priti K.

description:
Delayed on the review, but better late than never. I visited this place about a month ago. The lights weren't on during the day. Granted there was enough daylight out, but I wasn't the only one confused if they were open or not. 

Food was pretty good. I got the chicken pho and imperial rolls. The imperial rolls are kind of expensive for only being 4 pieces, but they were alright. They're really crunchy, so crunchy that it almost turned into a chewing battle because the outer shell is fried hard. The pho was comforting though. The broth tasted delicious like homemade chicken stock.

Not totally convinced that I would prefer this place over a typical, cheaper pho place though. You'd hope that with higher prices, food quality would be better or that there would be a dash of something special to the mix. I didn't quite find that to be the case here, but it was still overall a good experience.
author: Stacey L.

description:
i love getting the chicken pho soup when I'm in the area, after a healthcare visit...  
the menu says that it uses free range chicken...so that makes me happy...
I'm not sure about the comment someone else left on yelp about them using lots of MSG but I do hope that isn't in the soup because I truly love their soup!!  
customer service is nice, sweet and thoughtful :)  
I'm definitely recommend this spot!!
author: Deborah G.

description:
Best Pho I enjoyed in San Francisco 
Quick Services, Good Food and a pleasant atmosphere. The workinghours are also acceptable!
In the evening hours it could be longer. 7pm is Quitte early.
author: K. B.

description:
So many dislikes. We came here on a rainy afternoon after having an appointment at UCSF Mt. Zion.

They can't run an efficient business to please their customers. One guy just wanted a quick table so he asked a female patron if she would mind sharing her table. She didn't mind at all, but once he asked if he could share a table (opening up more space for others), they said "one check per table." They also seated a party of two at a table for four, making us wait yet another 10 minutes for the other table for four to open up.

We looked at the menu while waiting, so I knew I wanted the #12. ch nem cua, however they were completely out of it. Already not feeling well and not getting the one thing on the menu that I wanted, I ordered the #10. gà satay with noodles instead of rice. Our food came out and it was disappointing. 

Not worth it. Never again.
author: Leana L.

description: So let me preface this with I've been coming to this restaurant for over 5 years. I go because the food is good and reasonably priced. But each time I've gone over the last year or two the service gets worse and worse. The service used to be excellent. The food is quite good. But today the waitress got my order wrong and was frustrated with ME. She didn't say anything nice, wasn't apologetic, and didn't say anything to me as I was leaving. She just looked annoyed with me. Which I didn't appreciate. I'm not expecting a grand show of remorse or anything. But a simple oops. I'm sorry let me fix it. Would have been nice. I'll give it one more go especially since I'm all about second chances. But if the service is bad again, I'm going to the guys with the amazing sandwich shop on the corner. They're always friendly, with great customer service, and are always happy to see me.
author: Anjani A.

description:
I want to support businesses like this, but I'm sorry that I can't.  I had qualms about getting pho from such a mi chang place, but I wanted soup and this was *real close to work.  There was a huge lunch rush, the wait was 40 minutes!  I ordered pho tai to go and it was very quick.  The cashier was nice and friendly.

I thought this could've been great, possibly a Northern equivalent to Blossom in LA...but unfortunately, I was highly unimpressed with the broth.  I like the Northern style noodles, but still over all wasn't thrilled about my meal.  It was nice to have on a chilly day, but overpriced for a bowl of bland pho.
author: Lyn C.

description:
super clean viet spot (definitely the best in the immediate neighborhood). try to keep in mind that this is northern style vietnamese and most of the other vietnamese restaurants around are southern...which means it might be a little different than what you're used to. i tend to stop by here when i don't want to take the 38 into the richmond.

the pho is very good (woo for fat noodles!), meat isn't too fatty. last time i came here i ordered the beef special, but only got the regular size. i definitely wished i got the large for just a dollar more.

the thai tea is brewed well and not too heavy on the condensed milk. i love stopping by for spring rolls after yoga (again, very clean eating here). their peanut sauce is super unique and has coconut oil mixed in. YUM.

service is always friendly and efficient. i love sitting at the tables near the windows and watching the world go by.
author: Vanessa S.

description: Whenever I have a doctor's appointment in The City, I reward myself with some of the best chicken pho I have ever encountered.  I am usually alone since most appointments are made while the kiddos are in school.  The simple, pure, minimalist atmosphere are mirrored in their savory broth.  Each spoonful relaxes my mind and I can't help but to breath in the savory aroma.  The rice noodles are divine and the lightly flavored chicken complements perfectly.  I have had a ton of Pho all over the Bay Area, and My Father's Kitchen is the only place that truley keeps my full attention while eating.  Go get lost in a wonderful bowl of Pho.
author: Sara P.

description: If you're hungry and you want a little spot to stay and eat some warm, hearty food then this is the perfect place. I love the Pho here and Pho Gai. Pure excellence. But a reminder: always give them tip.
author: Abigail S.

description:
Pricier than what I'm used to for smaller amounts. 

Chicken pho: small is $8. Where's the chicken?? I get a lot more for cheaper  at other places. The broth was good though especially for a cold day.

Imperial rolls: 4 for $7.50. Pricey but it was good.

Overall, good food, and very convenient for UCSF workers yay! I'll keep coming just because I like Vietnamese food.
author: Corinna T.

description:
Clearly I ordered the wrong item on the wrong day. 

I ordered #12: crispy imperial rolls , crab, wild shrimp, pork, served with fresh herbs, rice vermicelli, and fish sauce.

I only got 3 egg rolls, vermicelli, herbs, and fish sauce in my order. Where's the crab, wild shrimp, and pork that was listed?! I thought it might be hidden under the enormous mound of wilted herbs but there was nothing. The worst parts is, everything was inedible! 

The egg rolls were definitely not fresh. The skin was thick, chewy, and hard as a rock. I tried the filling and guess what? It was sour.

I had to throw everything away. 

Never again. I'll stick with my mother's kitchen instead.
author: Annie N.

description:
Not real Vietnamese. Food just fine and overpriced. 
It didn't taste good. Lack of ingredients, sorry :-( .
I just don't recommend this place.
author: Sergio R.

description:
With the abundance of Vietnamese restaurants in the neighborhood, My Father's Kitchen almost has a monopoly on pho and rice dishes. They specialize on chosen, quality food - a glance at the menu won't overwhelm you as it does at other places. 

Starters, pho, rice and vermicelli noodles. As other reviewers pointed out, this is Northern Vietnamese pho, focusing on the basics: no sprouts or basil, but fresh meat, a tasty broth, and thick noodles. My favorite here is the BEEF PHO ($9) - can't go wrong with that.

Prices - it's not the Tenderloin or Sunset... expect to pay $9 for a pho and $11/12 for noodles dishes. Well worth it though as the restaurant is clean, presentation nice, and service friendly.

Noteworthy: The coffee selection includes Blue Bottle drip, nice addition to the Vietnamese coffee.
author: Sebastian F.

description:
I'm giving an extra star from my last review.  Sure, this is not the best Vietnamese food that's out there, but this is a great spot.  I am officially addicted to the peanut sauce that comes with the spring rolls.  I don't know how they make it so good.  And the five spice chicken is so tasty.  Sure it takes a little work to chop up the greens and mix them with the rice and chicken and sauce, but it is worth the work.  

The service is always great, the place is clean, and it's reasonably priced.  There is a reason this place is packed every day for lunch.
author: Paul W.

description: Love this place!  I've been here a couple times before volunteering and I can't wait to go back again to have more pho ga or try something else.  It's a popular lunch spot for the area as food is quick, filling and yummy here.  Hmmm, maybe I will go back again next week!
author: Maile N.

description:
I love this place, and I love Pho, and (a potential caveat) I'm a white guy.  So, although many people may argue there is better Pho in SF or somewhere else in the Bay Area, I keep coming back to this place.  Its Northern style, so not as many fixins (bamboo shoots, basil, etc.) but the place is clean with friendly decent service, the broth is tasty and healing, the chicken and beef pho both seem clean and tender and do the trick for my cravings.  I usually come on off hours, so not sure how the wait is for lunch.  They also serve blue bottle coffee, which is great.

I've been searching for places that embody the SF dining scene of farm to table, organic, pasture raised, or at least free range chicken and beef, not sure if this place does or not.  I feel like this place is underrated, so keep doing what you are doing, you have fans!
author: Trent S.

description:
This place is right in the 'hood, but the hours are kinda inconvenient.  They close at 7pm every night, so it is not often I can get my act together to get there by 6:30.  

We went there tonight. I had the five spice chicken platter, and my husband had the imperial roll plate (#9 & #12 respectively).  The #9 was $9, #12 was $12 (coincidence?).  

My chicken was good - two very thinly pounded (thighs?) with a glaze, served with rice, a salad (and a fish saucy thing). I asked for a side of peanut sauce, which was a peanut sauce with a coconut milk base. (my man tasted mine and asked for a side of his own.

It was a respectable meal for $9.
author: Amy W.

description:
Perfect food fir a cold day in the city . 
Fresh, hot 
Spring rolls awesome 
# 4 soup was perfect !
author: Bruno G.

description:
Perhaps the mother should have done a bit more cooking, because I did not find this very tasty at all. In addition to essentially no vegetarian items on the menu, what I was able to order was bland, and the price for the portions was high. Lots of the food is apparently pre-made, as they told me they couldn't make certain items vegetarian even though it would be easy to make them vegetarian by simply not putting an item in it (and then told me it as pre-made).

Since their food was almost all meat, I didn't want to be the only person to judge it. But the rest of my party also said they were not fond of it. 

It's okay though my kids don't like my cooking much either.
author: Micah A.

description: This place is great! Nothing fancy but the pho is delicious and I also love the spring roles.  The staff is always attentive and sweet and very fast.  My only complaint is that they close at 7PM, a bit early...at least stay open to 8!
author: Chelsea W.

description:
Came here on a very busy Saturday lunch.. Service is at 5 star !!! Only once White girl doing everything Host.. Sever and Busgirl ..she has the Best Composure!! Greet you with a smile n yet very precise in things she do.. I don't know what I Order but says 11!!! Happy with the outcome .. Healthy alternative!!!! Would I come back here!!! YES!!!!


By the Way Kate the only Server has The Biggest Smile.. Still Manage to smile n say goodbyes!!  Kudos !!
author: Donovan L.

description: This is a northern style Vietnamese. Basically, it does not include the multiple vegetables you would expect with your. They do not serve any meatballs. The noodles are not as thin. The coffee is not thick, however, I am not sure if this is due to a different style or that the coffee is just bad coffee. The food is average tasting and not worth the prices.
author: Dana D.

description: I LOVE this place.  They know me by face and name because I always get the same thing-thai iced tea and the fresh spring rolls (with no pork).  The food and the quality of the food is consistent and fresh.  I have yet to find another place that does their spring rolls as good as My Father's Kitchen and the slightly warm peanut sauce--heaven.
author: Andrea J.

description:
Excellent  place. Love their soups !!
The  Servers are remarkable, friendly  and 
professionals. 
I am a frequent  customer
author: Adrian S.

description: Nothing I ordered here was tasty. The imperial rolls were terribly hard, the five spice chicken wasn't tender or juicy, the papaya salad wasn't fresh and lacked in flavor, and finally, the pork over vermicelli was like jerky. Suffice to say I won't be returning here, ever.
author: Amy C.

description:
This serves "Northern" Vietnamese-style pho, so be aware that hoisin sauce won't be available - just sriracha! I've only ever gotten the pho ga (chicken pho) here, and it is SO GOOD. If you know of Turtle Tower, it's a very similar dish, and I thought they tasted comparable. Thicker noodles, deliciously light chicken broth, and you can ask for white meat only. Plus, it's free-range chicken! Dope. I've gotten a bowl when I was feeling under the weather, and it was perfect. The fresh rolls here are also really good, and that peanut sauce is bomb! I just wish it didn't close so early, because I can basically never eat here for dinner during the weekday - only during the weekend.

tl;dr Pho ga (chicken pho) and fresh rolls are the bomb!
author: Grace D.

description:
I was in the neighborhood and decided to eat here again. Previously, I had the pho bowl. I liked it. This time around, I decided to get one of their vermicelli plates (#12 on the menu). From the description, I wouldn't have expected it to be just the noodles, lettuce, and rolls (without any other meat not in the rolls). I've had plates like this before, but I guess it's always better to ask. 

Overall service was good. It's never busy when I come (in the afternoon) so there's always seating. Food comes out pretty quick. Pricing is pretty fair (check out the menu pic). Also, like the name suggests, this restaurant seems to be family owned. 

If I'm in the neighborhood again, I would order the pho bowl.
author: Shelby B.

description:
I love this place. I have been here about 4 times now and really love the soups. They are so hot and satisfying. It is true comfort-food. I know this sounds weird, but I've never got sick, and I have a sensitive tummy, after decades of being poisoned by my mom (unintentionally, through bad hygeine). The rolls are nice, but the soup is in really generous portions and comes to you fast, no matter what time of day or night!
Yay!
author: Kevin F.

description: I work down the street from this place.  I might have been here for lunch about 30 times by now.  The waitresses still don't greet me like a regular.  They are rude as hell.  I probably still come because a nice bowl of pho on a cold rainy day is nice. But wait, it isn't even that great of a bowl.  They're FAST though.  I'll give them that much.
author: Seema S.

description:
I tried the beef pho. The broth was good and didn't taste like it was loaded with MSG. The pho was wider than the typical kind but it was still good. They don't serve pho with all the normal sides like basil, sprouts...etc. 

The vietnamese coffee was really strong which is to be expected, but it was also really bitter in flavor. I couldn't finish mine.
author: Tammy C.

description: Service was nice. Food was not good. Egg roll were hard, like frozen too long or over fried. And they were $8 for 2 rolls!!!!!!! I was hoping they would be flaky and crispy. The pho was strange. The noodles were not normal, but tasted okay. The soup was below average. I would not come back.
author: Tina L.

description:
Don't go unless you are white or know a white friend who will go with you.

Me and my friend were checking a nearby set of condos for sale nearby and thought this would be a decent place to get some dinner since I had not eaten anything all day.  He was skeptical about the 3.5 stars however, I liked the decor and was willing to try out the place despite it's rating, unfortunately I was probably better off not bothering to go here.

We go in, got seated by a waitress/hostess with our menus quickly.  We waited 5 minutes as we looked at our menus.  After deciding on what we wanted, I told my friend to order for us if someone comes by to serve us and I left to go use the bathroom for a couple of minutes and came out and wait a few more minutes.  A white couple comes in, sits down without being seated and asks us for our menus.   Given that we knew what we wanted for some time now, I handed them the menu that we no longer needed.  I thought "hey restaurants don't rely on seeing who has menus to serve them right?"  We were the only table aside from the couple next to us who needed serving, the restaurant was sparsely populated today due to rain so they were not busy.  The point is there wasn't a lot to track.  

Unfortunately, the waiter comes over to the white couple's table and starts serving them.  And they make their orders, I ask if the waiter can take our orders since we've arrived before the couple and waited a much longer time.  He seemed puzzled and asked if we needed menus.  I told him we already received our menus and I gave them over to the couple he was serving since we already decided.

So the same waitress/hostess who seated us and gave us our menus 10 minutes or more ago, came out and finally to finally take our order.  She asked if we needed menus despite giving us menus 10 minutes ago.  I told her I gave the couple the menu and proceeded to ask if this restaurant only serves white people because clearly we had to claw our way to give our order while the white couple behind us sat down without being shown their seats and was served a minute after.

I told her #3 and #8 and she left to submit her order.

I was mad but we finally got our order so I let by gone be by gone.  

A minute later she came out and approached us to give us the lemon for the pho I ordered and with an angry tone she told us that this restaurant was not racist and that we were not served because we didn't have our menus despite receiving the menus from her just 10 minutes ago.  After that spewing, she stomped off into the kitchen, clearly mad that we were upset over being served after a couple who arrived after us.

This really put the nail in the coffin and what really pushed me into writing this review.  I've been to many restaurants, good, bad, terrible and received bad service but usually because the restaurant served everyone badly or because the restaurant was just so busy.  However, this restaurant was not busy and was giving good service to everyone except the 2 Asian guys.

We left the restaurant after her rant fearing there would be spit or worst in our food.
author: Thang T.

description:
I'm a frequent to-go orderer, so much so that they recognize my voice and know my order - that's earning your tip right there :) 

Not only are the staff and owner friendly and kind, but the food is amazing. 

My favorites: #9 with peanut sauce instead of fish sauce, Fresh rolls, and on a cold day Pho. 

Come, enjoy this yummy food or get it to go and eat it in your PJs at home.....
author: Christine V.

description: The food is DELICIOUS (pho & papaya salad are MUSTS) but the service is not great. They're on their phones the entire time and as a customer, I felt neglected.. so I had to give them a 4*
author: Phoebe M.

description: OK Pho. I had the brisket flank pho, broth didn't have too much depth but was passable, noodles were wide flat ones instead of my preferred thin rice noodles. No plum sauce on the table, did not come with the traditional garnishes I love, like Thai basil, raw bean sprouts, lime, chili, etc. Kills the craving but doesn't make you crave more - but I do have high standards from my local DC pho spot! Imperial rolls are good very crunchy and hot. Coffee looks good!
author: Margaret D.

description: Not my favorite flat noodles. Short and choppy. Broth is good. Spring rolls are good. It sauce taste like peanut and butter mixed with water.
author: Stacey T.

description: Authentic and delicious Vietnamese cuisine. Great place and good service. A must visit restaurant if you are in Divisadero of Fillmore street. Highly recommend it.
author: Devan K.

description:
I can't believe this place doesn't have at least 4 stars. They have one of the best bowls of broth I've ever had. Leaps and bounds above Turtle Tower. It seems many reviewers' chief complaints is that they don't serve it the way they're used to, which probably means they don't give the sprouts, basil, and hoison you often get at Pho restaurants. But I spoke with the owner and she assured me that her recipe is the way her father served it, and it's in the Northern style. So while it might be different, that doesn't mean low quality at all. It's quite the opposite. She focuses on the flavors already in the soup, and it is really apparent. The flavors feel cleaner, more distinct and robust than other Pho restaurants, that to me just taste salty and muddled. But if you feel the need to add some of the ingredients you're used to, just ask!

The owner is so passionate about what she's serving. Each bowl of soup is like a warm hug from her to you. Their care comes through in their food, but also in the customer service and decor and cleanliness of the restaurant. 

Watch out because the lines at lunch time are super long. And they close early as well, so if you're planning to try it for dinner definitely note their hours.
author: David L.

description: Interesting interpretation of localized family recipe dishes. Very authentic and a unique flavor makes this place worthwhile.
author: Svea B.

description:
I come here weekly as I work on the same street 5 days a week, and I love their papaya salad, their chicken satay dish, or their chicken soup. 

This is a spot that is not my typical go-to pho spot, as I'm used to different noodles and having bean sprouts with jalepenos, mint, basil, etc. served on the side, but their other dishes and great service make up for it.
author: April S.

description:
I am trying to get a pulse on this place. It is definitely a pho place but more on the French side of Vietnam. Don't get me wrong they still have the pho, the rice plates, the vermicelli plates, shrimp rolls etc. It's the small differences like no Thai basil and bean sprouts with your pho as you would get at other pho places I've been to. But still good. 

Just FYI
author: Angel G.

description:
I don't typically eat northern style pho, but when I do - I eat at My Father's Kitchen. lol jk It was my first time and I was impressed. The flat noodles were cooked well; although I could have eaten more flank steak and brisket. Most importantly, the broth was just right (broth is always the deal breaker) and the reason I liked it was because it wasn't ridiculously salty; honestly, it was just right whereas I often find myself drinking 10 cups of water after pho.

Verdict - Grubby likes it. It's simple and done well. You can't go wrong with a hot bowl of pho at MFK!
author: Mateo G.

description: I was surprised by some of the really low reviews. It is very conveniently located across the street from the Mt Zion medical center. The menu is limited -- soups and a couple of chicken dishes. The soups were really good, very satisfying.
author: Jen G.

description:
Northern Vietnamese food!  This place is a bit pricier than most pho places but really took us back to Hanoi.  We visit northern Vietnam last year and the food here is authentic and delicious.

We share imperial rolls, bun cha thit nuong and a pho tai.  Everything was delicious!!
author: claudia y.

description:
I ordered the pho togo and it was great! Service was nice, and venue was clean. Although I did arrive right then they closed. 

I would definitely come back again. They do close rather earlier in the day though, so check their hours of operation if you're thinking about coming in the afternoon.
author: Elson T.

description:
Went here a while back while my friend was in town. 

My Father's Kitchen is a family-owned business -- and a great one at that. Their take on pho is Northern style, so you don't get the bells and whistles you do at other pho places, but their food is still fantastic. The broth is fresh and the portion is substantial. 

Giving this 5 stars because the owners is such a kind woman who took the time to chat with us for 10-15 minutes. Her story is amazing, and I wish her restaurant nothing but the best!
author: Varun G.

description:
I got the beef combo pho.

I was really confused, I thought they forgot to give the bean sprouts but I remember reading somewhere that Northern style does not offer those. So I double checked on Yelp and looks like this is how it's done.

Pretty good pho.
The broth had a lot of flavor.
The noodles are flat and broad.

It's right across UCSF medical center and to a couple Kaisers so it's a good place for lunch, but it can get really busy.
author: Imma P.

description:
I didn't find their pho delicious at all or even special. It's a bit more like northern style pho but Turtle Tower is heaps better. I went in craving traditional pho with Basil, Lime, Sprouts, & Chile slices. This pho was actually quite forgetable. The only reason I added a star is for the convenience of being one of the only Vietnamese restaurants close to UCSF on Divisadero. 

The beer and wine prices were OUTRAGEOUS at $10 a glass.

I also found it very unusual and slightly unwelcoming that the staff were Russian or Ukrainian. The food was naff. A true dissapointment!
author: Julian I.

description: I like how the sign says they open at 11:00 but at 11:02 you see a lady (who works there) sitting inside eating her piping hot pho looking back at you and another lady (who works there) in the kitchen comes around to see who's at the door and I'm standing outside in the cold watching them both watching me. It's ok... Their pho was mediocre anyways. Go to Ly's over the hill on Lombard or Turtle Tower in TL.. Much more worth it to stand in the cold and wait, at least they'll open the door to let you in. Oh and mind you that I was standing out there waiting for 11:00 to come around for a good 10 min, so don't pretend you never saw me out there
author: annie w.

description: Cute concept. The pho is served without beansprouts or basil - when asked the response is "this is northern style" which is silly because...pho. The broth is a little "hard" as a Vietnamese mother would say and the noodles were not of the fresh assorted one. It's a convenient bite of pho but not an authentic bite.
author: Annie W.

description: The beef pho is heaven! And the spring rolls are so fresh and delicious. Always prompt and kind service.
author: Lois L.

description: Across from UCSF, I went here for some comfort food before treatment. Had chicken soup with rice noodles. So good, so comforting, so going back. What a treasure to have across from the infusion center.
author: Russ H.

description:
I know I shouldn't be comparing this place to any other Vietnamese place, but I'm going to.

The pho I had was edible. By edible, I mean that the food was decent enough that I would have turned it down and gone somewhere else. The broth flavoring was off by a good amount (maybe an additive or something that wasn't beef). The noodles were the flat wider ones that are not pho appropriate, and there wasn't any basil mint leaves for us to tear into my soup, already placed in there.

The atmosphere itself wasn't the greatest, as I was seated with my friend, near the wall, where two other tables around us, and I had to excuse myself to both parties as I was leaving the place.

Not the best place to go get Vietnamese food, but it's edible.
author: Tom T.

description: I ordered the beef noodle pho. It was below mediocre. The broth is what makes the soup and it was okay. I had to add a lot of siracha.
author: Kristy A.

description:
This place is legit.  I'm Vietnamese.  I've had a lot of pho, including in Vietnam.  This is really really good pho.  I had the chicken pho and the chicken was super tender and soft.  You could taste the free-range flavor.  And the broth was superb.  Their noodles are bigger than the usual noodles, which I love.  It was so good I wanted to lick the bowl clean.

I also had the imperial rolls (ch giò) and they were great.

I don't know why this place doesn't have 5 stars.  The place was extremely busy during lunch.
author: Julia W.

description:
The Pho is good, not great. The broth didn't meet our expectations.  It lacked the typical meaty flavor that gives this dish its character, also portion was much smaller than other restaurants.

We've found better places in the avenues and TL.  It's not a bad option for convenience, but wouldn't go out of our way.
author: Zoran L.

description: Đàn ông nâu bêp có khác, chú ai mà phõ gà đàc biêt lai có môt nam tay to thit bò tái, hay là phõ thâp câm?Thèm khung khiêp thì ăn cho đo ghiên, chú phâm chât chi trung bình thôi. Nhung My thì mê lám, xêp hàng dài tranh nhau ăn.
author: Lam N.

description: "My Father's Kitchen" serves very simplistic, clean food.  Their broth for the Pho is very good, and it you don't have to add a bunch of extra ingredients to enhance the flavors.I would definitely return here again the next time we're in SF.
author: Bio G.

description:
Very fast, good value and yummy. I had 20 min to grab a late lunch before an appointment across the street at UCSF. I was nervous about the time I had but my spring rolls and papaya salad came out within minutes, and I was early to my appt! 

It was surprisingly full (2/3 maybe) at 3pm, would guess lunchtime is tough here

Good fresh food and reasonably priced (think $16 incl tax tip for two dishes)
author: Aki N.

description: The food is quite good but is it just me or are the portions way too small? Well, it's not just me because several of my friends have said the same thing. Need proof? Just look at the pics on Yelp of their imperial rolls. The bowls for the pho need to be bigger and the serving sizes for their riceplates are going to leave you still hungry. And they are not cheap for a Vietnamese restaurant so there's no excuse. This place could definitely get more stars if they weren't so stingy.
author: Vincent L.

description:
The pho was "rat tot" (Vietnamese for very good, without the accents)!

Prepared well. Service good and fast. Nice and clean restaurant.
author: Marc B.

description: Just across from Mt. Zion by Sutter St. Very basic pho. Beef and chicken were good. A bit pricey but it is SF. Tables crammed together so you will likely sit next to a stranger. All the other food looks fresh and appetizing. I like the Vietnamese coffee that drips right at the table.  We may have to come back to try other dishes.
author: Lee O.

description: Nice little local family run biz that presents a comfort food aspect to Pho.  While a bit pricey, the food quality is good and fresh.  It's conveniently located across from Zion UCSF Medical building, so if you are visiting there or waiting patiently with a patient, go there to get the pho for lunch or perhaps take out the fresh spring rolls as a snack or light dinner.
author: Mitzi A.

description:
While I was there a man was served noodles with grilled beef.  He did not know that the sauce was under the noodles and needed to be tossed.  He asked for olive oil.  The waitress (not Viet or Asian) said she didn't have any.  Then he proceeded to dowse the noodles with straight NUOC Mam.  Yikes! Followed by salt and pepper.  Then out of desperation because it still didn't taste right, he asked for satay sauce.  If only the waitress had known to tell him, clearly a first time diner, that the sauce is included in the bowl.  I watched this hapless routine but didn't want to intrude.  Still, it was a disquieting experience as the staff should be alert to someone not familiar with the food. I bet the man will never eat there again.

Although many single diners, the staff made people wait until they got their OWN table. People in a hurry don't mind sharing tables.  It's convivial and contributes to sense of community.  In Viet Nam everyone eats at communal tables at Pho Joints.  

Just an observation.
author: Nhu M.

description:
Underwhelmed would be the word,went in yesterday for the 1st time for a while,my wife and I used to talk this place up to our friends,but not anymore.I have no idea if the owners changed or a new chef/cook came in but the quality of the food has seriously gone down the toilet,pretty much tasteless,whether this food has been dumbed down the the American taste I have no idea.The spring rolls,chicken and papaya salad were bland as heck the sauces were non existent in taste,the coffee was so weak it was a disgrace.The overuse of silantro and mint was horrendous,both my wife and I had indigestion for the rest of the day after this meal.
Plus as someone who works in the bar/restaurant industry the fact that the server did not once ask if the food was ok is unknown,the fact that it came to our table within 5 minutes of ordering pretty much assured me that all this food is prepared beforehand and without doubt not made fresh to order.
Its a shame because when I 1st started going there the food was stellar..Oh well
Really Really Really Dissapointing
author: John R.

description: I was on Divisadero St and really wanted pho for lunch. There was really nothing around except for this place. Basically, this is one of modernized pho place that has pretty interior design but serve only average pho. This place much reminded me of "Out the door" on Bush St. The price is definitely more expensive compared to those traditional pho places like Kevin's noodle house. I paid $10 for a "large" beef noodle soup, which was smaller than the medium sized pho from Kevin's noodle house. However, the taste was not bad. The broth was good, rice noodle was good and so was the beef qualify. Although it was not amazing, it serves the purpose of providing warm and comforting noodle soup for the UCSF neighborhood. One thing that needs to be pointed out is that the pho doesn't come with bean sprouts. I think that's the way Northern Vietnamese cuisine is ( correct me if I'm wrong). Anyway, definitely not a place that I will go out of my way to visit again. But if I were in the area and happened to be craving for pho, I will definitely come back.
author: Siian X.

description: It was exactly what I expect when I order pho. Nothing special
author: Jemara G.

description:
People complain about the prices; I would have zero problems throwing $12 at a bowl of Kevins noodles if I could secure one without a 20 minute commute in both directions.

The food is ok, certainly not great and it tastes like it has been white washed. (which is attributed to its northernness, but which also makes sense given its location.
author: Donald C.

description:
My Father's Kitchen serves decent enough pho, but the portions are small for the price you pay.  Their large size bowl ($9-10) is more like most other restaurants small to medium size bowls.  Your bowl will have more noodles in it than anything else, but will have no more than 2 ounces of meat (depending on the kind of pho you choose), a sprinkling of green onion, a sprinkling of cilantro, three thin slices of jalapeno, and a small lemon wedge.  Good for a snack, but not if you're starving hungry.  If you're in the neighborhood and just absolutely, positively have to have pho, then My Father's Kitchen will probably satisfy your craving and hit the spot, especially with the cold weather we've been having lately.   

I really don't see myself becoming a regular of My Father's Kitchen, though, for the following reasons:  

1. The place is pretty small and cramped, with the tables jammed close together.  So, you'll basically have no privacy whatsoever, if that's what you want.  It's more like a communal seating situation, but minus any feeling of congeniality among you and the other patrons. 

2. The two main waitresses here have no real clue about how to provide good customer service.  I sat down to eat here twice and both times, I felt very unwelcome.  No hello or smiles during the whole time of service, just plop the menu in front of you, give you your food, and that's about it.  I was left with the feeling that they prefer a certain type of customer here because I noticed how those people were treated better consistently.

3. If you choose to order your food to go, my advice would be to wait outside the door in front of the restaurant, instead of trying to sit down on any of the chairs they place on the opposite of their kitchen.  If you do, you will constantly have to maneuver yourself so that the servers don't bump into you as they are trying to serve the customers at the tables.  And, don't even think of sitting down at an empty table to wait for your to-go order.  You will be rudely directed to sit at the side chairs instead. 

The only person that makes an attempt at providing acceptable customer service is the cashier.  At least she knows how to smile and say thank you.
    

Food Taste/Quality 2.5 stars
Portion Size to Price 1 star
Waitress Staff - 1 star
Other Customer Service Staff/Kitchen 2 stars
author: Danielle O.

description: Best spring rolls in the city hands down. Clean, simple, reliably fresh and good.
author: Ronald B.

description:
I have been to this restaurant a few times long time ago, and always thought it was just okay. Recently I was at Kaiser for an appointment and couldn't eat anything until after the appointment, so I came in for a late lunch and was really hungry. 

Normally, if I am that hungry, everything should taste great! But the meal was ok at best. First, the imperial roll was really chewy. I had really great imperial rolls elsewhere and never this chewy and was wondering why. The only time I had imperial rolls this chewy was when I did take away and ate the imperial roll much later and micro it. I am not saying they micro their rolls, but whatever they are doing, it reminded me of that. Then, I had the big bowl of pho tai. I don't know the difference between their big and small because the bowl here is pretty small compared to other pho places. Also, they are supposedly Northern so they don't even give you bean sprouts or the basil to put into your soup. Just a slice of lemon and some jalepeno. The taste is just average. It's not very flavorful and I am disappointed by the really watery broth. I guess the only upside about this meal is maybe due to the less than stellar flavor, they are also not as salty like other Pho places. Maybe they are very mind-ful of salt intake due to the restaurant being near two hospital facilities. Hopefully that's it. 

I went after lunch rush, so service was ok.
author: Missy X.

description: First of all this is not your typical Vietnamese pho joint. It's authentic yes, but none of the staff is actually Vietnamese; they're all in the back making the magic happen. You can never go wrong with pho ga, which is my pho of choice. Here, It's consistently well prepared and always hearty. The fresh spring rolls are probably the the BEST thing on the menu, WHY? It's because of their peanut sauce! They should probably start calling it PEANUT-BUTTER sauce cause that's whats in it...Always made to perfection and fresh. If you're dining solo for lunch you can get a half-order, score!
author: Caye Q.

description: We have seen this restaurant many times and today we needed to wait two hours for our doctors appointment. We love this type of food and this place ranks up there with some of the best of them. We had their soup and we judge by their broth and noodles
author: John P.

description: So happy to have found this place. First, the service is excellent, so friendly and inviting and they work hard to be quick. The pho is to die for, I love the handmade noodles and the broth is just right. This truly is Vietnamese comfort food at its best, closest thing I've found in SF to what I ate in Hanoi.
author: Annie R.

description: Food is authentic and flavorful. Service is great and friendly. Always busy but that is a compliment to their good work. Worth the wait.
author: George S.

description:
I love the bun mee with grilled pork, pork meatballs and fish sauce. So yum! The service is average, they could be friendlier because alot of people who come here either work at the nearby hospital, are visiting someone sick or have a doctor's appointment. In other words, possibly emotionally fragile folks who need a friendly smile. 

Regardless, the food is excellent! In fact, I may head down there today to have lunch!
author: Katie T.

description: Really good pho with quality ingredients and a clean restaurant. Price are good too of course. Hours are limited so check before you go.
author: Natasha F.

description:
Pricy for pho with small portions and it doesn't taste authentic.  Don't expect to get full here if you're hungry. For one person and a small bowl of beef + chicken pho it came out to be $10 something ! That's expensive. 

No thanks, I don't think I will be back paying for expensive and bland pho.
author: Lucy C.

description:
I ordered a free range chicken pho with rice noodles.  They serve Northern style pho, which means there's less fixins and more emphasis on the broth's subtle flavors (though they do provide a lemon wedge and jalapeño slices). The broth certainly delivered - warm, wholesome, flavorful. 

The waitresses were sweet and bubbly. I came in right after the lunch rush, so the place was quiet and the food came fast.
author: Michelle J.

description:
Date & Time:  Friday March 26, 2010 @ 2pm
Dining Companion:  The Husband
Scene:  Mix of 20-30 Somethings in Small Groups Guys in Baseball Caps, Shades & Tats & Girls in SpringTime Tops & UCSF Staff
Vibe:  Chill
Decor: Contemporary & Minimalistic.  Warmly Painted Walls w/ Framed Black & White Photos.  Dark Wooden Tables
Service:  Sweet Lovely Girl & Outgoing Guy
Imbibe:  Blue Bottle Drip Coffee & Vietnamese Coffee
Devour:  Rare Steak Pho & Five Spice Grilled Chicken
Total:  $20.50
author: Genevieve Y.

description: I ordered a number 3-imperial rolls & it was really good. Although it was really busy, the customer service is really great because they try to accommodate to you as much as they can. Our server, Serena, was really nice and the food came fairly quickly- within 10 minutes.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Okay.. Seriously all the Vietnamese restaurant that so far I went to end up being Chinese/vietnamese! The place is small, hella crowed cuz is next to kaiser n UCSF Mc! N also is a quick lunch! 

I ordered chicken noodles soup n crispy rolls! The broth is water down, however the chicken is fresh white meats so is good! :) As for my crispy spring rolls, omg is so chewy! Sigh... The price is alil pricey for the service and the foods the sale! 

First n LaST!
author: Lala B.

description:
People are such haters.. this place isn't bad at all. Hits the spot when you're craving a hot bowl of pho. I like that they have the combo of chicken and beef and the broth isn't too bad. It's a bit pricey but it is the only decent pho place around the area. During lunch hours be prepared to wait a bit and share a table if you're by yourself. 

Oh and they serve blue bottle coffee. Thumbs up.
author: Lynn C.

description: This is my favorite Vietnamese restaurant! Not only is the food amazing but the service is great. I would highly recommend it!
author: Katie P.

description: The nicest staff, but I'm just meh on the pho. Had one of the beef options - the noodles were different than other pho noodles I've had (softer? Differently shaped?), and the meat was just okay. Imperial rolls were serious business - pretty good, but the skin is thicker than my typical preference. I wanted to like this place so much more, but will probably skip it for somewhere on Clement in the future. :/
author: Shendi X.

description:
Wonderful vegetarian options in a traditionally non-vegetarian genre. 
Staff was very tolerant of our loud table.  Dark chocolate kisses at the end were mmmm.
I liked our server's coral colored lipstick. However, it would not make sense for me to order a lipstick online without trying it on.  Will continue the search for coral lipstick. I digress....
author: Zak R.

description:
I am a gluten free pescetarian, so there is only 1 entree, and 3 things total, on the menu that I can eat.
But I love those 3 things so very very much that in the last 6mths I have eaten here at least a dozen times! There is frequently a wait, because the place is rather small (maybe 12 tables), but even while 8mths pregnant I never was detured from waiting! I was thinking to come in tonight,  but alas, they are closed on Sundays.
author: Jessica R.

description: Flavorful delicious pho - even better than I remembered. Light on ingredients, but that's part of the simple beauty of it!
author: Kelsey T.

description:
Limited menu but then the place is mostly a lunch joint catering to the teaming masses of health care workers employed at UCSF and KP. The #10 is fantastic. Curry chicken breast with a side of rice. Hints of fish and soy sauce also waft over the dish.  And let's not forget the peanut sauce. Mmmm, peanut sauce. So good.

The pho is also solid although I never succeed in having even half the greens it's served with. The staff is young and hip. Oh and they serve drip coffee for those interested in the hyped craze.
author: Jahan T.

description:
Was not good.
Tasted bland as ever.
And they charge for tea wtf is that about.
Sorry guys I tried to like you.
author: Calvin S.

description: Love this little place. The staff is young but super friendly and the owner is lovely.   I am not a Pho expert, but the food tastes excellent and is of high quality. The slow cooked chicken has never been dry or overdone the way it can be in many places.  I think the prices are very reasonable.  Highly recommend.
author: don M.

description:
