Have been here before and had to crawl over other diners to sit down.  Today I was at a table I could reach standing up but the food seems to have gone downhill -bland liquid and noodles was the special pho- finding the beef and chicken was difficult. 
Service was really spotty. Bill was shoved at me before I finished my soup or started my coffee. Try something different next time!
author: Fran H.

description:
I think sometimes it's worth giving a place stars not for superb food, but for what they offer.

1. Early start time.

2. Pretty fast food to grab and go.

3. Some relief from the oppressive monotony of Burnt Butter Pete's next door, Starbucks microwavawiches and the MI-in-progress of the Cheesesteak Shop.

4. Not oppressively bad Viet food. Light, decent broth, can spice to taste.
author: Rafael S.

description:
Is it a detination?  Meaning, if you live 20 miles away, do you gather your friends and head to this place, talking all the way about how amazing it's going to be?

No.

So what is it?  It's a terrific neighborhood restaurant.  Solid food, expertly prepared.  Service with a smile.  Reasonably priced, the sort of place that could quickly become a once a week habit after work when you just want the same thing you always order, brought by the same person you always order it from.

What did Hemingway yearn for?  Ah.  A clean and well-lighted place.  Well here it is.  If you're in the neighborhood, drop by.  If you're headed to the Independent, step off the 38 (or 38L), turn right on Divisadero and have a quick dinner.
author: Rob F.

description: Average tasting Vietnamese food. Our Vietnamese iced coffee was super watered down after we asked them for some togo cups (we are thinking the water was added when they added the ice).....shoulda put it in the cups ourselves. Small little shop. Waitress was nice. Pho was average and I had a bun plate which was also kind of average. The bun was not like at other VN restuarants but came on a plate with everything separated. The plate didn't come with fish sauce but the sauce that came with the meat was good so i just subbed the fish sauce with that.
author: Aline D.

description:
The service her is always on point and super friendly. This place is always busy and they do their best to accommodate you and acknowledge when you walk in. Kelli is great:-)
This is not your typical traditional pho. They don't have the bean sprouts cilantro and mint to add. They make each order to taste. Very different and very delicious! I don't usually like the rice noodle but theirs to my amazement are so delicious. They are made fresh and delivered daily. A definite must try in the neighborhood!
author: Autumn C.

description:
I came here as soon as I was able after recovering from a nasty cold.   There is nothing like Pho Ga to help get over the hump.  I did get take out after seeing the reviews about the wait and that was a good choice- there were about 10 people waiting outside for a table.  

The broth of the soup was very good and flavorful and if I'm sick, that's what I really need is some good homemade broth.  I didn't really care that the noodles were the wider ones. The chicken was fine, maybe a little dry, but pretty good and a little dark and light meat.   What I was kind of bummed about was that every other time I've ever had Pho, it comes with a nice pile of garnishes, like basil, sprouts, lime and hoisin sauce.    I happened to have Sriracha and garlic chili sauce at home, but I missed the other stuff.   

I might come back to try some Spring Rolls or maybe another dish.  I didn't think the price was bad considering the rents in the neighborhood must be pretty high.  The service seemed nice and they sure are close. 

I seldom get nostalgic for Seattle, but when it comes to Pho, Teriyaki and Thai, I just haven't had the same experience since moving to SF.  And it has been 7 years.  Maybe soon I will get lucky.
author: Maria C.

description:
Came back and got the pho and grilled chicken rice dish...which were exceptional.

Since my first visit, the taste was really different and I loved the pho this time...although I felt weird afterwards and wonder if there was MSG in it as I only feel the way I did after MSG exposure - but since I can't confirm it I won't assume it to be true.

Again got a cafe sua da of course...

Great place...much improved from my first visit almost a year ago!
author: Julia P.

description:
Pros: close to work, open, clean, courteous waiters

Cons: ran out of brisket, almost ran out of noodles at 7pm (we were the lucky last ones!), had to ask for cilantro and oyster sauce (basics for pho if you ask me), $9 for spring rolls just doesn't seem worth it to me.

Overall, an alright place. I ordered pho ga. Keep in mind that small here really does mean small.
author: Xixi C.

description:
It's ok for what it is.  What is it you ask? A clean well done Vietnamese establishment. However, it really didn't feel that authentic for me. The small bowl didn't have much in it. The noodles weren't the typical pho noodles. They don't have bean sprouts for you like every other pho place I've been to in America. 

Was it tasty? yes. Just different, and a little pricey for Vietnamese food in general.  Glad I tried it but probably wouldn't go back.
author: Ricky F.

description: Cute little place to get great Pho, great service and even catch the game! I super sick and all I wanted was some yummy pho and this was the ticket for sure. Only reason I have 4 stars and not 5 is because I wish they had more vegetarian or seafood (shrimp) options. Not the biggest fan of chicken and beef so a little more variety would be great! Other than that no complaints- huge pho portions, a small was plenty! And the people are so nice :) will def be coming back soon
author: Rebecca K.

description:
3-4 stars is about right, primarily because there aren't a ton of other great options nearby. I wouldn't recommend traveling far for it but if you work in the area, it's a solid lunch option. The pho is solid northern-ish style (you can ask for hoisin sauce on the side if you prefer it) and the vermicelli plates are overpriced but good. 

P.S. good service but I get the douchechills anytime a server refers to me as "boss" or "chief."
author: Baron C.

description:
My Father's Kitchen is right across the street from the Mt Zion campus of UCSF. This is just a few blocks from where I used to live.There is a dearth of Pho establishments for many blocks. This one has been opened for little over a year. 

I really wanted to like this place.

It looks like a dive from the outside, but walking in, it has a nice, clean, simple decor, with wood tables and chairs, wood floor, and mini-spotlight track lighting. 

The service is really nice, too. The son serving and the mother cooking our day of visit were sweet. 

The Cha Gio (deep fried egg rolls) is very good, much lighter and crispier than most places. The Nuoc Mam (fish dipping sauce) is very sweet.

The dishes are not the plastic Chinese red and yellow designed bowls you can buy at 99 Ranch, but rather more upscale looking Dansk-like square white porcelain with raised lips and points, and the soup bowls are also a Danish modern all white, smaller and deeper than a Pho place would use. 

They only have a limited menu. The Pho comes in about 6 - 8 versions, including Pho Bo Dac Biet (beef special combo) and Pho Ga Dac Biet (chicken special). The smalls are about $7 - $7.50. 

I didn't like the Pho, however. Perhaps it is more of a northern style, as the owner is half Chinese and half Vietnamese, and everyone working spoke Cantonese, not Vietnamese. 

They use the wide, flat fettucini like rice noodle rather than the more common vermicelli type. The Bo Dac Biet meats were nice and tasty. But the Pho broth was very flat to me, more like what i would find in Chinese Won Ton Mein soup. In fact, it tasted like chicken broth to me. 

Also, they served greens with the Cha Gio, but not with the Pho. Instead, they served little condiment dishes with sliced chili peppers and an orange slice? Or maybe it was tangelo? It was not sweet, but it was not lemon or lime. No sprouts, no greens. 

I also had to ask for Hoisin sauce, which I usually put on a condiment dish with Tung Ot Sriracha, and dip my beef into so as not to spoil the broth. 

So if you can't make up your mind between a bowl of Chinese noodle and Vietnamese noodle soups, come here and you will get a little of  both. 

PS - they really cater to the lunch and UCSF crowd, because they are only open from 9am to 7pm. They could do more business at night, because people in the neighborhood came by but were turned away.
author: Wanugee N.

description:
Pros: 
1. soup was piping hot
2. There was fish sauce available on the table (have only seen a handful of restaurants that do this)

Cons:
1. Soup was bland
2. Noodle was soggy
3. Noodle was 1-2x wider than the pho noodle I'm used to
4. Expensive for pho. Large is actually a small in other restaurants. $9 for a large, the most expensive pho I've ever had. Very little noodle and meats in the soup
5. Not important to me but might be to others (I don't eat this part): rare steak was fully cooked and shriveled up (i'm guessing it would have been very chewy if I ate it)
          
Service: everyone seemed friendly except for the girl who brought me my soup -she did so without even looking at me, seemed as though she was just passing by and begrudgingly had my soup so she was forced to drop it off
author: T K.

description:
Vietnamese coffee - Pretty delicious and hot!
Spring rolls- super good, simple veggies, yummy wrap and even better peanut sauce
Pho Ga- Most flavorful broth ever, chicken is tender, super comforting
Service- AWESOME! Friendly dudes up in here
author: Mario M.

description:
1 star for use of MSG, I have an allergy, and although I love their soups, I couldn't pinpoint the exact cause of the facial tingling/tightness, dizziness and blurred vision I had after eating them until I read a bit more about MSG allergies. I'm a nurse and used reputable sources to read up on symptoms (pub med). MSG may not effect individuals who don't have a sensitivity, but WHY use an in ingredient that may be harmful if you don't have to??

I won't be back.
author: Elisabeth G.

description:
Good Pho.. I wish they stayed open later. 

I live in the neighborhood and can only go here on Saturday during the day because I usually get home too late during the week. If they stayed open until 8pm I would give 5 stars
author: Benjamin N.

description:
Pros:
- pho ga was decent
- quick service

Cons:
- inconvenient hours (closes at 7pm! I don't usually get off work earlier than this)
- food was not memorable
- a bit pricey for the portion size

Bottom line: The inconvenient hours and mediocre food is not worth it. I recommend trying one of the many other restaurants on Divisadero.
author: Jiann M.

description:
It's a pretty decent place. I live right next door and the pho is alright, but lacked the vegetable options like sprouts, cilantro, etc. You get a lemon I believe and that is it. The chicken curry dish is pretty small for how much it costs, but has good flavor.

All in all, its just got a good atmosphere, but the food doesn't live up to it. Try it out once for the pho and see what you think. Its good for a try at least!
author: Jarrett R.

description:
Love this place.  Service is very attentive and friendly (the main male server always calls me "chief" and "boss," which I appreciate), pho always hit the spot, and the appetizers are delicious.

I will definitely say that the space is a little cramped, but that doesn't take away from the great experiences that I've had here.  My go-to local pho spot and I don't feel the need to try anywhere else!
author: Joey M.

description: Had the pho ga which had an excellent broth and homemade noodles! Fresh jalapeño on the side was a bonus. Having just come back from a trip to Vietnam, these noodles are probably just as delicious as what I ate over there! A small is really a lot of food, I could barely finish it! Next time I go I'm going to try the bun vermicelli noodles!
author: Jennifer H.

description: Best chicken pho I've ever had! Spring rolls and Zinfandel are very nice too! Will recommend for lunch.
author: Mariya Delilah D.

description: Hands down the best Vietnamese food in a long time.  In order a #8 chicken over rice with peanut satay sauce.  Yummy. Very small so don't expect to dine in but great as to go!
author: M R.

description: This place makes my heart warm. It's delicious food served quickly. Downside is the lunchtime rush. Go at off-peak  hours to enjoy an even more peaceful meal.
author: Caroline T.

description:
What a cute little noodle shop.  The decor is simple . . .just black and white photographs of Vietnamese life (people in rice paddy hats, working the land and fishing).  The menu was simple as well.  Just a few offerings. . . Vietnamese comfort food is the tag line.  We felt comforted, indeed :)

It was a bit on the pricey side, but we quickly became accustomed to everything being on the pricey side in San Francisco. 

I got to chat with the owner/manager very briefly and discovered that it was run by people from Northern Vietnam (judging by her accent and formal use of the language-the South of Vietnam is full of asian hilbillies like yours truly ;P).  This explained the subtle differences in the way the pho tasted and how it was served.

When you walk in, you are immediately engulfed by the aromatic blanket of the pho broth.  Because I am a self-proclaimed noodle expert, I could tell right away that the broth was not beef-based.  Or if it was, the flavors had not seeped enough.  Maybe we were there too early in the day, it wasn't even 10am yet :)

I guessed that it may have been a chicken-based broth, not that there is anything wrong with that.  You tend to get a clearer and cleaner taste when you use chicken bones, but I always prefer to use beef bones.  Nonetheless, the soup hit the spot.  Northerners tend not to eat bean sprouts with their pho (which is just fine with this non-eating bean sprout yellow girl).

We also had their imperial egg rolls.  Soooo delicious!  Their nuoc mam sauce tasted light, fresh and citrusy, not nearly as hot enough, but you can always modify to your taste.

The cafe sua da (Vietnamese iced coffee with condensed milk) was creamy goodness, but I don't think it was quite strong enough, not like the cafe du monde coffee that is brewed here in Houston's Vietnamese noodle shops.

The best part:  The pho noodles are made and delivered fresh daily by a shop down the street! I asked the server about them because they were so different (from the traditional banh pho noodle). You could tell by texture and taste that they were special.  Bigger, wider noodles that were perfect for this soup!

Don't miss My Father's Kitchen when you are in the Fillmore/Divisadero area of San Francisco!
author: Cuc L.

description:
I came here because my co-workers wanted something cheap and we thought Pho was a good idea. On the outside this place looks pretty cool and we just walked right in. The menu choices werent much but they have the usual pho that is small or large. Usually the small will fill me up and large was wayyyy too much when I ate at other pho places. 

Ok. Why the 3 stars? portion. Comparing this to a lot of other pho places in inner richmond their portion is kind of poor with that kind of price. I agree with some yelpers here that imperial rolls were about the same price as the pho was kind of lame. Their small bowl was REALLY small and on top of that, the noodles werent the noodles what a lot of pho places usually use. At pho garden, you get more choices of meat and the portion is way bigger for a small. My co-worker ordered the rice with chicken and it was so tiny and expensive for what it was. 

Other than the portion everything else was "ok". It wouldnt get me back here anytime soon but I will probably come back if I wanted pho that is close to work.
author: Jade L.

description:
Not that it matters, but none of the wait staff speaks Vietnamese here, so when I tried  asking about a few specials in Vietnamese, that didn't go anywhere. That really doesn't affect the rest of the review, though, more of a heads up than anything.

The pho dac biet was just okay. The broth was fairly flat and needed fish sauce to give it the kick it deserved (which they strangely had on the table...?). I don't mean dipping nuoc mam (fish sauce) but the kind that you have in a gigantic bottle in the kitchen. 

It's made with the traditional garnishes, but the lack of sides (lime, bean sprouts, etc.) was a big no-no to me. No matter what, if you're serving pho, you should have the traditional side garnishes. I realize this place serves a multitude of Vietnamese dishes, but not having the chopsticks, spoons, dipping saucers, hoison sauce, sriracha, and chili paste on the table made this place feel extremely unfamiliar. In general, there wasn't a Vietnamese feel to this place at all.

The wait staff were at least polite and attentive. They don't serve ice with the water, though, which is another weird thing to me (probably more of a pet peeve than anything).

Wouldn't really recommend it, but if you absolutely can't find another pho joint, it's satisfactory.

Edit: Forgot to mention that for pho, they use broad noodles, which is really bizarre. Their bun thit nuong (barbecue pork w/ vermicelli rice noodles) isn't really that appetizing either.
author: Skippy T.

description:
I've come here a few times due to its convenient proximity to UCSF. If you choose to dine-in, I hope you're skinny because the seats are super close together and you'll be getting cozy close to your neighbors on both sides. I had to navigate my way very cautiously in order to not knock into anything around me. Moving on...

The spring rolls with the peanut sauce is the best dish here! The ingredients are so fresh and the flavor combination is absolutely delicious. The peanut sauce is so scrumptious that I make sure to use every last bit of it. Yum. You must try this if you come here. I didn't care for the pho though. There wasn't enough flavor in the broth. The dish was pretty bland. There wasn't anything special about it. I usually love pho but I wouldn't come here for pho. I do like that they offer Blue Bottle Coffee though. 

The service is friendly. I recommend taking your food to go if the place is busy.
author: Nancy C.

description:
They call it "Vietnamese comfort food, however there's not much that's comforting about this place. I've ate there a few times but only return for the coffee. The pho was disappointing to say the least. 

The first time I had the pho, I was sick and just needed something to warm me up. It hit the spot. I chalked up the unflavored broth to me being ill. Little did I know, that's just how they prepare their food. 

My next visit was with a coworker, we each had pho because it was one of those bone chilling days in The City. He loves pho, like we always swap stories and locations of our favorite eateries.(he should start Yelping) 

We were both saddened by our meals. Bland broth with very little noodles and meat. The only accoutrement that accompanied this big bowl of suck was sprouts and a single wedge of lemon. I had to snag a bottle of Siracha from an adjacent table. Where was the mint, the lime, the fish oil, the chili oil, THE BASIL!?

Overall I was very disappointed, traumatized for life. I didn't know that pho could be screwed up that bad. My coworker called it, "White person pho."

The only saving grace of this posh Vietnamese eatery is the coffee; Blue Bottle. 'nuff said.
author: Justin C.

description:
The first thing you have to understand when you go into My Father's Kitchen is that it's NORTHERN Vietnamese cuisine, which is different from the Southern Vietnamese cooking that is 99% of the viet places you find in the city. My mother being from Saigon in the south, I'm biased towards Southern cuisine which everyone agrees (including Northerners, much to their distaste) is much more rich, flavorful, and generally sweeter of a palate. The northerners pride themselves on a simple (and in my opinion, bland) palate, much like the Japanese. This is why you don't find the extra condiments on the table at Northern Vietnamese restaurants. They don't believe in it. It's just something you have to come to terms with and you cannot expect otherwise without sounding like a demanding and ignorant tourist.

That being said, My Father's Kitchen rocked the pho. It came with the signature northern style wide noodle, and the broth was actually very well done and flavorful, which is actually a departure from the old school Vietnamese diaspora in SF. Ever been to Turtle Castle in the Tenderloin? Their pho is practically vegetable broth. Tasteless. No condiments, overcooked beef, very northern viet. But the pho at father's kitchen was very good and far from bland. There was tender loving care in that bowl of noodle soup, and I was jealous of the beautiful woman across from me consuming it. 

I was having the Bun Cha Thit Nuoung, which is basically pork meatballs and grilled pork in a sweet vinegary fishsauce filled bowl served alongside fresh mint, lettuce, and thin rice vermicelli, and that was also great. This dish is very northern, and I had it all the time while I studied abroad in Hanoi. They nailed it. Actually, they did it much better than I remember, which is usually the case because it's hard to match the quality of meat we have here in California compared to the overworked farm cattle they serve on the streets of Vietnam. 

The service was very nice, and the waiters attentive and chummy. I am definitely going back, especially as I passed bright yellow plates of curry chicken over rice while on my way out from a very satisfying lunch.

I'll have to come here more than once to give it five stars, but otherwise this place is a sure bet.
author: Ben P.

description: Great food, service was awesome! Atmosphere really nice, vietnamese beer always helps...
author: Seommoro V.

description:
Very cozy little place. The food was greattttt and they were super fast, we had the classic chicken and meat pho soup that was super gooood and the spring rolls were excellent.
Will definitely come back.
author: Blanche E.

description:
Amazing food, Amazing service, great price,  this gets an A+
I found this place walking by and I was impressed with their tasty and healthy choices, also the service here is great and waitresses are so kind!!
author: Alex T.

description: Very tasty soup, and friendly and helpful staff. I would eat here again. The only downside is that it's a bit small. I've also had  the chicken satay and rice plate, which was good, but I think the soup is the better option here.
author: Greg C.

description:
Best pho in the city!! There hours can be a little weird, I think they serve more of a lunch crowd on weekdays with the hospital right there. Portions are really good size. A small pho feels like a large pho, I can't imagine how big the large is. 

The staff was awesome, explained the menu and was attentive. Will be back next time I'm craving pho.!
author: Carlynn A.

description:
-Food (Pho Only): 5/5 stars
Their Pho is the best I've had in the city, and it's also the only dish I've ordered here.  Broth is absolutely superb, and while the meat isn't sliced as thin as I would like, the plentiful amounts they provide more than makes up for it's thick-sliced nature.  I typically enjoy thin rice noodles moreso than the flat variety, but MFK's flat noodles are excellent.

-Service: 3/5 stars
The older woman with short hair is very solid (She's really not old, likely 30-something, but she's definatly got a few years on most of the servers), I'm assuming she is the daughter of the father of which the kitchen belongs to.  Seems like a family joint, where friends and family of the owner appear to be running the show.  Service doesn't suck, but it certainly has room for improvement.

-Decor: 4/5 stars
Gotta be the cleanest Pho place i've been to.  Far less grungy than all the other 'authentic' vietnamese pho spots, which I originally held against MFK, but soon conceded that filth is not a neccessary ingreiant for my soup to be delicious.


OTHER NOTES:

-WTF? no hoison or soy sauce on the tables.  Fear not, just ask and they'll bring some out.
-If someone your with needs immediate medical attention, there's usually at least five customers with MD's dining alongside of you.
-Place gets real busy between 11:30am and 1:00pm for the UCSF lunch rush
-EARLY DINNER ONLY (closes at 7pm) and CLOSED ON SUNDAYS!
author: Kyle S.

description:
Feeling under the weather? Go to My Father's Kitchen - soul warming bowls of rice noodle soup with lean pieces of chicken (or beef) and a broth of clean and vibrant flavors. Comes with slices of jalapeno and a wedge of lemon on the side for an optional kick. Depending on your hunger, they offer small or large servings.

Their menu also includes spring rolls, crispy imperial rolls, green papaya salad (those items also come in a vegetarian model); beef rice noodle soup; two rice plates - 5-spice chicken and grilled boneless chicken with satay sauce; two cold noodle salads - one with chunks of meat, the other with imperial rolls; beverages include: Blue Bottle drip coffee, hot & cold Vietnamese coffee with condensed milk, Mighty Leaf teas, sodas, San Pellegrinos, OJ, beer and wine. They also have Patisserie Philippe baked goods.

Clean and modern (West Elm-like) space. Be sure to get there before 7pm Monday thru Saturday. Closed on Sundays.
author: Cathy K.

description:
I heart this place, esp when I have the sniffles. 

The difference between a small and large bowl of Pho is indistinguishable to me, and I usually go for the large (and either eat it all, very hungry, or save half!)

They are clear when you ask about their Northern Vietnam origin, but will gladly give you Hoisin or Fish Sauce or whatever else you want for your Pho. Initially I did add to it, but then I got used to the more simple yet great flavors and appreciate the difference in getting Pho here than other places.

Also, this place is just adorable. Always friendly staff. You can linger or have a quick meal. Super clean!
author: Sarah X.

description: Love this spot - great Pho, easy service, I frequent here often!
author: Kate M.

description:
If you are a vegetarian, stick with the appetizers. The mango salad and the imperial rolls were amazing. They don't have a vegetarian pho on their menu and the Cha Nem Cua just seemed to be missing something with out the meat. My friend enjoyed his pho.

I'm sure I'll be back, just because I'll be craving their crispy imperial rolls.
author: Katie L.

description:
Had the salad, nice and crisp
+ Tasted fresh and made to order
+ Conveniently located right next to UCSF if I want to grab a quick bite after an appointment
- Menu short, limited variety for vegetarians

Conclusion: I need to come back here and try the pho. And the shrimp rolls, i hear they are bomb
author: Julia D.

description:
They serve blue bottle coffee! They are Zagat rated.  I should stop my review here but I'm going to continue...

We split the bun (vermicelli) with imperial rolls & the satay chicken plate.
 The chicken was not very generous like other Vietnamese places but Unlike other Vietnamese places, it was absolutely delicious. 
Each plate came with a ton of greens. I actually made lettuce wraps with my vermicelli, added some cilantro & thai basil. The only thing that dish was missing was some type of meat.  The Imperial rolls were delicious, again different than what you're used to. I swear I sensed a little bit of cinnamon, dessert-like like flakiness, almost tasted baked v.fried....

Our waitress was very pleasant; she's 1 of those people you would just go back to see again for some reason. Lovely personality :)
The truth be told, the day we went in was the last spot of our adventure for my friends birthday. We started the day strolling Golden Gate Park, ended up at Frankies for beer(s) & splitting a bomb Brambory, then saw a happy hour sign on the way to get foot massages so we had to go in and get happy right? We then had fantastic foot massages at UtoEpia and decided to wind down with a light dinner. We got our bodies beat by Asian uncertified massage therapists & arrived at this quaint restaurant pretty zombie- like. 

My Fathers Kitchen has an extremely simple menu which was heaven for us considering what we were working with. Again don't expect it to be the 8 page long typical Vietnamese menu. I think there may have been 12-14 options total & that includes about 5 appetizers, 3pho options, 2 rice plates,  2 vermicelli options, & coffee/tea. I have no idea if they have beer or wine we were not needing anymore etOH.

They deserve 5 stars: food, service, quality & cleanliness all can be found here. And if you read my reviews you could see that I am a little picky. Not nit picky just picky. Some even more gently consider it being selective.  It's a good thing especially when there so many options and I'm not just talking about food.

 If I worked close by, I would definitely be here more often. Highly recommended.
author: Athena S.

description:
Today I had the pho with rare steak, spring rolls and a hot jasmine tea. A little steep on the prices but hey its SF what do you expect.

I thought that the spring rolls were very delicious but the peanut sauce i was less excited about. Tasted like Jiffy that had been warmed up and mixed with coconut milk. It was also separating and had a small pool of grease on top, never seen that before. 

The pho was delicious even without Hoisin sauce which they are happy to provide upon request.  The broth was light and flavorful. I really liked the wider noodles. Those were pretty good. 

Service was great during the whole meal. Then at the end when she brought my receipt to sign she said your total was 17.40 but the other girl accidentally rang it up as 17.46, here is a quarter to make up the difference, we are SOO sorry. I was shocked and impressed, I would never have even noticed not to mention giving me a quarter for a 6 cent mistake. Way to go above and beyond.
author: Jennifer G.

description:
Absentee father.

Evocative name has you already rooting for them before you even step inside the small space with a lot of character.

Appreciated the option to have my pho prepared with all white chicken meat.

Unfortunately that's where the praise ends. Pho was good but not memorable. Staff disappeared for extended periods of time. Blue Bottle coffee was overpriced.

Wanted to like more than I did. Sometimes father does not know best.
author: Jason B.

description: I wouldn't say this place is traditional Vietnamese food, but it's pretty good if you don't expect that. A bowl of pho on a chilly SF day, split some imperial rolls (I've only seen that in SF). Full belly for ~$10. Tiny spot so gets full fast, get here before 12!
author: Vivian H.

description: Really fresh food! I got their pho and my friend got a rice noodles dish with plenty of fresh veggies! The service was really good, they agreed to split our appetizer order into half spring rolls and half crispy rolls. Very reasonable prices too!
author: Michelle Z.

description:
Geez. This place has such great aspirations, but really fell short on my expectations. Tip: Don't have any because you're sure to be disappointed.  The place is cute and has nice ambience. I went there for lunch with my co-workers and it felt good to be there. It's on the small side, and it's super buzzing with all the people who work nearby.  So it's hard to find a table if it's busy. Uh Duh.
My co-workers ordered pho, one chicken and one beef. I ordered a rice plate (grilled chicken with satay sauce over rice). It came, it looked exactly like I DID NOT expect. Not bad, just not what I expected. I need to practice what I preach. One thing I can say about my dish is that the chicken was very tender. I liked the tenderness of the meat, nice and soft. Well pounded. The flavor was... eh. I was NOT impressed and I didn't even eat a fourth of my food. Someone would have liked it (my husband ate it at midnight for he had the munchies), but not moi, said Sharon. The satay sauce it came with didn't even help. It was bland and I even added the hot chili sauce to it. Nada. It kicked it up a notch but the notch was tiny. Very dissatisfied with my lunch, all I wanted was to stuff my face with some sinful ass gelato, to kill a memory of a bad lunch. My co-workers loved their pho, so don't worry, I hope I didn't totally bash them for your own experience. Oh wait, their fresh spring rolls were ok, the peanut sauce it came with was SUPER BLAND. Would I go back? Nah, I'm cool.
But they're very cost efficient!
author: Sharon B.

description:
Yum! 
Fresh delicious green papaya salad; house drip bluebottle coffee.  For the neighborhood this is an excellent healthy and yummy, reasonably priced option.
author: Best M.

description:
Not my favorite pho.

The broth is decent, but not hearty enough.

The bun is waaaaay too many veggies with oddly crispy rolls.
author: David J.

description:
Stuck at Kaiser all day because you are sick?  Don't worry.  You can get yummy, healthy soup at My Father's Kitchen, the only nearby pho option.  The menu is small, but everything is delicious.  Pho bowls come with thick rice noodles (and though I prefer egg in general), these are amazing!
Also, even if you are in your sweat pants and look awful as you head to the doctor, I have never had anything but really friendly, kind service here.
author: Aileen J.

description: Big thumbs DOWN. Worst Pho I've ever had in my life and the service was about as bad as the soup if not worse. Tables were sticky and dirty and the waitress did noy ask me once if I needed anything. The soup was bland not to mention there was no hot sauce other than siracha. Complete disappointment.
author: Maria T.

description:
OK this is not a four-star joint.  But if you work at UCSF, it's a place that you can get a meal that:
1. Does not cost more than $10
2. Will not stop your heart with a large wad of fat while you are still eating
3. Will not make you smell like raw garlic just in time for your next patient visit

By the way did you know Yelp does not allow a 'greater than' symbol in their reviews?

The front desk guy is really LA, right?  Like, he's glad he had time to leave his Method studio to kick it a little here, but he's not going to get excited about anything.

Rock on man.

This is not exactly Vietnamese food.
author: Carun J.

description: The service is always friendly and the food never disappoints!  I've come here 10 times in 6 months! #11, 12 are great for non pho!
author: Rebecca E.

description: Decent pho place in lower Pac Heights.  Friendly staff and small little place and the pho was pretty good.
author: Blake B.

description: Solid northern-style pho bò: no bean sprouts, no extra sugar (a nice alternative to the sweeter southern-style Vietnamese cooking that you get most places) - it's simple and authentic.  Amusingly, the servers don't speak a word of Vietnamese, but the talent is in the kitchen where it matters most.
author: Stephen A.

description:
A great little neighborhood dine.

Just didn't think that the pho broth had a lot of depth to it.  

Portions were a bit on the small side for the price.

There are a ton of better alternatives a mile or two away on Clement.
author: mike y.

description: Pho soup was good enough to visit it  at least once a week.
author: Monika W.

description:
I was craving pho because of my hangover and searched the closest location to me. This was the best option, and I'm very glad I discovered this place even though they didn't serve tripe...

QUICK TANGENT: Tripe absorbs your hangover and cures you by 6:00pm same day. Try it!!! Works 100% of the time.

Any way... this place is a lot different from what I had envisioned in my mind. If you're expecting a rundown mom/pop - forget about it. It's actually a cozy little space that's pretty well designed. Minimalist and tranquil. Service is also fast and attentive.

I ordered a #4 small bowl of chicken pho for $8. Overpriced...but it was delicious nonetheless. It tasted clean and fresh. I can expect anything else I order to be presented in the very same way. I'll probably be adding this place on my list of places to visit again.
author: Paul B.

description: I love this place. It's right near UCSF, and getting to stop here after is the silver lining of having to see a doctor. The pho ga is a particular highlight and is better than much of what I had when I was in Vietnam
author: Catherine S.

description: Weird hours, weird service. Our introduction to Pho had specific accompaniments that this place openly snubbed. Regional snobbery? Meh. Ain't nobody got time for that. Bring me what I want and don't poopoo me. I mean, this sure isn't fine dining. Besides. The meat in the phô is tougher than my shoes. Watched them turn away to-go business even though they had taken our eat-in order minutes before. Poor form father.
author: James S.

description: I ordered the imperial rolls to go. For paying $8.50, I received 2 rolls no more than 5 inches in length, small sauce and 2 pieces of lettuce.  They included a lot of mint. Perhaps to cover up the little amount of food.
author: Anthony G.

description: I've been here for lunch when the place can get pretty crowded and it can be hard to navigate between the tables because they're so close together. The place is clean and the service is good but the food doesn't taste that authentic, more like a watered down Americanized version of Vietnamese food.
author: Shirley S.

description: This place is southern Vietnamese so it's a little different. They don't give you the goodies on the side which I really love. Bowls are small too
author: Victoria G.

description:
I gave it a try since I was impressed by the its look. Its very simple but clean and deluxe (not like other Pho restaurants)

The Pho was just ok. Not bad but not outstanding. Its not the real Vietnamese Pho noodle though. Its probably cooked by Chinese cooks. I did get very thirsty after it because of the MSG.

At other places, I always order a small one and I can barely finish it. However, today I was not very hungry but I order a large one since the small one looks small. Yes the large one filled with lots of broth and not much noodle and meat!!!! The broth leftover is enough to make a new blow!!!! I do not spend more money just to drink MSG!!!!

I was there around 4pm. It got dark early because of the winter. However, no lights were on. Other customers and I were eating in the dark!!!!!!!!! The only light we got was from the kitchen. I told a waitress about it and she said the lights were broken and they get broke every 3 days and there is nothing she can do about!!!!! WHT? then get better light system! I wonder how customers can eat their dinner!

The most annoying thing was the sound from the waitress boot/heel. She walked around making noises from her boot on the hardwood floor. Hello its working and its not a fashion show! the boot may look pretty on you but it makes annoying noise!

Overall, I can find this kind of MSG Pho anywhere but at least I dont have to eat in the dark with annoying noises! Its like torture! I came there to enjoy foods but not to being torture!

I would not come back and would not recommend it to anyone else!
author: Petit L.

description:
I went to this restaurant with a few friends for lunch since it was close to the medical facility. I saw that there were a few better rated Vietnamese places nearby but my friend said that she didn't have time to go to a place further away so we settled on this place. 

When we walked in, we weren't greeted immediately even though the restaurant was not that busy. Not a big issue, but not a great start either. The decor of the place looked pretty nice so we decided to stay. We each ordered a rice plate and they came out fairly quickly, so no complaints there. 

The satay chicken rice plate was decent but I thought that the five spice chicken plate was pretty good. As my friend was picking through the leaves of lettuce that came with her five spice chicken plate, she noticed a dark colored chunk of something. She just placed it aside, but decided to closely inspect the rest of her lettuce. And it is at that point where she found a CATERPILLAR crawling around on her lettuce. WTF! 

One of the waitresses noticed our puzzled faces and so she came over to check on us. We notified her of the issue quietly, but she just responded, "O! There's a caterpillar on your lettuce? That's a good thing!" Uh.. maybe it is, maybe it isn't. Either way, my friend no longer felt like eating her lettuce. Then another waiter came over and picked up the lettuce that my friend had placed on the side of her plate and muttered a very insincere, sorry. Beyond that, there was nothing that was done to make up for it. 

The rest of us stopped eating, since we didn't feel quite as hungry anymore and paid quickly (the full bill) so that we could leave. We don't think we will return. But if eating bugs and receiving poor service is what you like, then this is your place!
author: Chris K.

description:
Good, focused menu.  The pho is Northern Vietnamese, so you will not get the same set of vegetable accompaniments you would at other restaurants, but that's fine since it is a different style.  You get lime and some hot green peppers.   

The com phan (rice plate) is good, and I had the one with the five spice grilled chicken (they use Mary's chicken).  I like places that do a few things well, rather than trying to be all things for all people with a huge menu.

It can get crowded right around lunchtime.
author: Dan C.

description:
I was in the neighborhood to see a hand surgeon. I explained that I had a bruised jaw and couldn't really chew. They made me chicken soup with extra broth. This was extra sweet of them. 

When I went back a week later, they remembered me and asked about my jaw. It was better---I got the imperial rolls---yum! But then I clumsily dropped one trying to eat with my left hand. I almost cried at the frustration of having a broken right hand and dropping something so delicious. They saw it happen, didn't say anything when they picked it up and then brought me a fresh one a minute later. wow. 

I had to switch doctors but I'm going back to the neighborhood (across town on muni) to satisfy my craving for this place. The food is amazing and they are really genuinely nice people that want their customers to feel good.
author: A R.

description: Really good pho for a great price! Under 10 bucks for a filling meal that is truly comfort food. Try the number 4 pho
author: Roxanne R.

description: Very good experience. I ordered the chicken and rice noodle pho. The broth was light and flavorful. Came with sliced jalapeños and lemon, which I used. Added a bit of vinegar and sriracha. The chicken tasted fresh, not frozen for a year Iike 99% of the Asian noodle soup restaurants out there. A huge plus. If I can't eat the meat I don't eat the soup. The Blue Bottle coffee was delicious and freshly brewed. They grind the beans for each cup. I would highly recommend this establishment to anyone.
author: Joe D.

description: Over priced Vietnamese food with a lack of options. Sad to think that the people here are actually trying to pass this off as "authentic" Vietnamese food. The noodles aren't the right kind, there's no bean sprouts, no hoisin sauce at the table (only available upon request), and the coffee isn't even the right grind. A definite skip on this Americanized establishment that they are trying to pass as "authentic" Vietnamese comfort food.
author: Justin D.

description:
The vermicelli bowl #11 is delicious! Very clean flavors, I enjoyed this more than the bun cha at Bodga Bistro or most anyplace else. 
The beef and chicken pho broth are excellent too.
author: Wakako U.

description: Great food.  I travel a lot to Asia and this is great Northern food.  Beef soup is tasty and robust.   Some people here complain about the price...and considering that this is a SF restaurant, the prices are very fair.  Quality is high and the portions were good.  I will come back hete!!!
author: Larry J.

description: Walked passed the restaurant while visiting San Fran.  Looked interesting so ducked inside for a bowl of chicken and beef food.  Was very good!  Was recently in Vietnam and have been searching for a bowl of pho as good as the real deal.  This was close. Simple, clean, lots of flavor.
author: Hugh G.

description: Great traditional northern style Vietnamese food. Great Pho, and deconstructed meals. Eat like the northerners, simple, fresh, and satisfying. Family business, brother sister front staff were cool, and fun to talk to.
author: Jeremiah K.

description:
Came here on a cold night, Pho soup seemed like the best thing!

This is not traditional Vietnamese food, they said it was Northern. When I got the PHO it didn't come with basil, beansprouts, limes, cilantro. The normal fixins. It was broth, with tofu (well I got the veggies style) and lemon.

I asked for basil but they didnt have it. They game me mint instead. I liked it, it was different. Not bad just different. Cute place tho.

I gotta come back and get some other dishes.
author: Jess O.

description: Great Pho place by UCSF Mt Zion (walking distance). I would recommend trying some of the different menu items not typical of all the other Pho places in San Francisco.
author: Ken L.

description:
I work right next to this place and eat there an average of 2-3 times a week... they're THAT good! Ive had everything on the menu... The chicken and rice plates (5 spice grilled chicken or the satay chicken), the # 8 beef soup is my go to or the spring rolls.  The staff is SUPER friendly, even when they're busy, which they usually are, they always acknowledge customers in a friendly and timely manner. Reading some of the reviews, I'm surprised most people didn't put 5 stars... and I've eaten there 100's of time and I've certainly never had a grasshopper in my food haha.

I just wish they were open on Sundays so I could take my brother, a lover of pho, here, oh well... we'll have to a make trip on Saturday!
author: Mariya P.

description: Came here for a quick bite to eat. We both had the noodle soup which was watery and bland. The chicken was dry. Overall my opinion is that if you're a Vietnamese restaurant that doesn't several good noodle soup you should just give it up.
author: Y A.

description:
This is really more 3.5 stars, because they're open all the time from 9am to 7pm  Mon - Fri, so if you need a hot bowl of soup at 10am or 3pm in chilly, foggy San Francisco, they'll have it ready for you in minutes.

My favorites here are the chicken satay with rice, and the Vietnamese coffee.  The chicken meat is tender but not very flavorful.  However, the satay sauce (that they serve on the side) is delicious and deserves 5 stars.   I've also tried the different varieties of pho (a bit bland, but very filling and clean-tasting) and the imperial rolls (delicious but the portion is small).

Service is usually friendly, although the staff can seem a bit harried especially during peak lunch hours when the line can go out the door and down the sidewalk.  There is practically no waiting area (you'll either have to stand outside or right inside the door, or sit on the chairs placed up against the kitchen counter, facing the eating clients).  I've also tried calling to order food for pick-up at around 12 noon, and kept trying until 12:15pm but no one ever picked it up at that time frame, so I just gave up.  Eventually I just learned to call at 11:30am to avoid the lunch rush.

All in all, a nice place for a quick lunch.
author: Petite G.

description:
Delicious Vietnamese food in a cute, unpretentious place.  

Been here a few times, service is always great. Can get crowded right the lunch hour (across from UCSF Mount Zion) but at 11am or 2pm it's mostly empty, and you can take as long as you want. 

Great place to dine alone too! 

For the people who say it's not authentic, they're wrong- it's Northern Vietnamese food!
author: Gary S.

description: The staff is very warm and welcoming. The food is great. If you can find parking or are in the area, I would recommend giving them a try.
author: Ernesto D.

description:
For a "americanized"  pho place, it's pretty good.

I think restaurants should focus on serving simple meals with simple ingredients and this is what this place does.  They do not have an extensive menu.  Their pho broth is really clean (not too fatty, no MSG taste).   And their eggrolls are the crispy real vietnamese skin kind.
author: Bianca P.

description:
Nice yummy pho for a rainy cold day. Shrimp rolls are heavenly. 

They're open early which is an added bonus if you want lunch at 10am. Awesome wait staff.
author: Taylor C.

description:
This is the real deal.  Real Vietnamese food cooked by Vietnamese people who really knows the food.  They serve real Northern Vietnamese Pho which is not serve with any Siracha hot sauce or plum sauce because that would just dilute the light broth that takes hours and a lot of chicken or beef bones to make.

I give the eggrolls (Imperial rolls) a two stars.  They can really do better.
The service and servers were really nice.
author: S C.

description: Cute spot that services the lunch scene around. Decent chicken pho, a bit salty (like most places) and bit scared on ingredients, but still does the trick. I fresh and fried egg rolls are very good, and the service is great.
author: Brian J.

description:
My husband was getting surgery next door and I needed to eat a quick bite while I waited. The ladies at the surgery center recommended My Father's Kitchen to me, so I walked over.

It's a simple menu - a few pho options, some salads and appetizer style meals. I had a "small" (it was huge!) pho with brisket and steak and it was DELISH! I also had a 1/2 order of the spring rolls, which were also super tasty. The price was right, the service was great - I'd absolutely go back!
author: Isabel M. L.

description:
I love Vietnamese food, especially goi cun (spring rolls). I love the variety and Americanized variety SF has to offer, but if you're feeling authentic Vietnamese, this is the place to go! 

I just scarfed down seriously the best authentic goi cun I've had in the city so far. The bathroom was clean, the order came out quick and the cashier/server dude was pretty cute and very friendly!
author: Kevin J.

description: One of my favorite lunch spots. Excellent, fresh ingredients and a quick turn around. Great service, also.
author: Chris M.

description:
I wanted to give this place 2 stars but there are many reasons why it does not deserve it.  Being Vietnamese, I know what good pho actually taste like and I'm not that picky when it comes to it.  If my mother was with me, she would have it sent back. 

The broth was SO BLAND that I had to add a bunch of sriracha sauce and it pretty much turned into a spicy soup that had no flavor but the sriracha itself. 

What really shocks me about this place is that I can hear the cooks speaking Vietnamese to each other.  I know they don't eat this crap at home so WHY?!@!!!!  

And then there's the price tag.  $6.5 for goi cuon (spring rolls)??????????  That is fcking bizarre.  How can two spring rolls cost a dollar less than the pho itself?  They must put crack in there and bad crack at that. 

I finished my soup to be polite but I was pissed at how bad it was because I know it could be better especially coming from Vietnamese chefs.  The chefs know the crowd they cater to and don't give jack shiz about quality cuz you people don't know what a good bowl of pho is!!  Or rather people don't seem to know what pho should actually taste like.

This ain't pho y'all!
author: Nho C.

description: I love this place. The food is authentic and a pleasure on the palate!  I've always enjoyed good service-  the atmosphere is quiet and elegant.
author: Paul N.

description:
Full disclosure... my husband is Vietnamese and Chinese so he has high standards for Vietnamese cuisine.  Me on the other hand, probably have a more Americanized palate.

I like this place!  I didn't have any high expectations, but the flavors of the pho and egg rolls are really nice.  I have a hard time paying a lot of money for Vietnamese food since it is one of the cheaper cuisines and my in-laws make it for free... so I would say that this place could lower their prices a bit.

The beef pho was nice.  I didn't taste any MSG, just clean flavors but if you are looking for meat... keep looking.  I want to say that my pho had 2 pieces maybe 3 pieces at the very most of small rare beef, which if you know anything about Vietnamese food is ludicrous... especially for $7.50 a bowl.  Also, there was no hoisin sauce in sight, I had to ask... um, really?

I will come here again when I have my next doctor's appointment at Mt. Zion, but this would not be the first pho or Vietnamese place that comes to mind.  Also, check out the egg rolls... pretty good in my book.
author: Tiffany L.

description: This is a little shout out to the people at My Father's Kitchen.  Your broth is amazing, and we love coming here, not just for the Pho, but for the people who work here.  Everyone of you is so nice and so welcoming.  We always feel like we are guests in your home, treated with care and love.  Keep doing what you're doing.  Thanks, Your Homeys
author: Chad H.

description:
Can not compare to turtle tower. I got the #4 pho ga with brisket and imperial roll. The broth was bland and the noodles  were yucky. Imperial roll was mediocre at best. What a disappointment!!!!

The waitress was very sweet and the decor of the place is cozy, but I would just go to turtle tower for a real kick ass pho ga!!!!!!!
author: Emily T.

description:
This is a very cute Vietnamese restaurant right across the street from UCSF Mt. Zion. The overall impression I got from the restaurant was a more classy, modern feel compared to all of the Vietnamese restaurants elsewhere (aka the Sunset).

Things to get:
(1) Pho Tai - rare beef pho. The portions are smaller than what I'm normally used to, but the broth was delicious!
(2) Bún Cha Thit Nuong - Vermicelli noodle dish with marinated grilled pork. This was definitely one of the best vermicelli dishes I've had in the city!
author: Liz W.

description: Well-deserved 4 stars.  Simple menu, reasonably priced, friendly & fast, and above all very yummy.  Highly recommend for lunch (it's a pity they don't stay open for dinner)
author: Philip I.

description: Love this place...the best Pho ever!  The spring rolls are bomb, and the peanut sauce is like melted peanutbutter cups...FREAKIN AMAZING!!  The staff is very friendly, and the cooks don't mess around...your food is up in no time.  I would give this place 5 stars because it's one of my SF favs; however, the parking sucks.  I almost got towed away last time I was there because I was parked in loading zone.  Tip: Don't park at the yellow parking meters....even if you put money in, they will tow you!
author: Brian D.

description: I have only had the pho and I am picky about my pho. This place serves thick noodles. I really liked it. Prices were right for lunch. Service was good. The place is a little small so get their early.
author: Kristin M.

description:
Little pho restaurant located across from ucsf medical center.

Service was effective and quick but by no means pleasant or friendly. Whatever it's lunch.

Imperial rolls: good! Very tight and dense with quite a strong white pepper character. Enjoyed the flavor but the density of the roll took away from the delicacy I enjoy in a good imperial roll. Nuoc chom was average, sweet and not that fishy or spiced.

Beef pho: very mediocre. The broth itself lacked flavor and depth. Interesting smokey note which was enjoyable. The meat itself was well cooked and succulent.

Consensus: mediocre overpriced Vietnamese food with average service in a convenient location. Would not return.
author: Gabriel W.

description:
My partner and have scoured the city for perfect pho.  As the years pass, we are more inclined to also consider the environment in which to enjoy pho.  

My Father's Kitchen offers great Northern Vietnamese pho served in a clean and comfortable setting.  The broth is flavorful, the meat is well prepared, and the noodles are perfect.  Even more satisfying are the spring rolls, which are served at perfect room temperature.  The service is always great.  For a Saturday afternoon lunch in the northeastern part of the city, My Father's Kitchen easily satisfies the week long craving for pho.
author: Michael P.

description:
Is it true?  Heaven found on Divisadero St?  Home made Pho that hits the spot married with Blue Bottle Coffee?  

This new place just opened up a few days ago.  Modern decor, family run, and great service.  I ordered the chicken pho, norther nVietnam stye, noodles a bit wider, served with lemon and slices of green chili.  It was sooooo yummy.  Authentic like the ones you would get in Hanoi. A big star + for no or little MSG.  Unlike other Pho places I usually have to down a big glass of water afterwards.

Of course finished it off with a blue bottle cup of coffee to go, served slightly above room temperature so that you can taste the true flavor of the coffee.  Big bow down to getting them to endorse your business. 

Will be back soon with hubby.. Though they don't open for dinner so will have to drag him during Saturday lunch.
author: Sam S.

description: Had their springs rolls which were not bad, but their chicken pho, which was pretty good, gave me that MSG headache, so pretty sure they use it. Otherwise the service was good and the blue bottle coffee and mighty leaf tea a good addition.
author: Svitlana T.

description: A large is sooo small. Ok quality otherwise. My 5 year old was able to finish two large orders, only here I guess.
author: William C.

description:
I've had better.
Too small. Too crowded.
And the Pho was sour. Is Pho supposed to be sour? 
Will not return.
author: Joe H.

description:
The Pho here is bland and I will never eat it again.  

The good:
- super clean
- blue bottle coffee available on pour over

The bad:
- bland/boring pho (I feel like I should have known by the general cleanliness of the establishment and quality coffee that the pho would be bad, so I am giving them a "my bad" star bringing it to 2)
- expensive pho (I'm used to paying $5-$6 for a small bowl)

Overall, I noticed a lot of people ordering the chicken satay, so I might give that a try (probably not).

I think you could safely get take out coffee from this place and leave happy.
author: sarah l.

description:
It wasn't bad. I've walked by this place many times and it attracted me with that modern sleek homey feel. I was a bit reluctant to try it though because I live in the inner sunset and there are tons and tons of Pho places around here (what could be better than Kevins?)... 

But it turned out to be one of those cold muggy Saturday mornings in SF and decided to stop in.

I got the impression that it wasn't as authentic as the name would lead you to believe- the menu wasn't littered with 137 combinations of meat cuts items that you could combine- the waitress didn't have an accent-no smoking insence buddah that i noticed.

Food wasn't bad either, though it didnt come with the typical basil, sauces, sprouts. The waitress said that it was Northern style and they didnt come with that. Soup flavor was okay. 

The highlight was this Vietnamese coffee that drips into the cup in front of you and is mixed with condensed milk. DELICIOUS. 

overall I would say 3.5 for trying to fool us into think it is super authentic when we live in SF and there are TONS of other pho places around. Good for a hot bowl of soup and coffee
author: Sirina K.

description:
The place looks really cute and I was excited to get a big bowl of pho on a cold and stormy night.

I got the beef pho.. and the beef tasted kinda weird. I'm not sure why. Also it had a weird texture. And it was this weird pale color, and it was cut into squares.. it was just plain weird. I found myself to be queasy from eating it.

I liked the noodles. I just ate the noodles and sipped the broth and left the beef.

So, yeah. I'm not sure if I fully trust the meat here after my experience. I kinda wish they had a hearty vegetable version on their menu!
author: Rachel H.

description:
I just flew back home from a little trip to NYC, and this is going to be my first stop after work today.  It's where I want to eat if I'm cold, tired, happy, warm, awake- any time.  My gf and I find ourselves there almost once a week.  

We are those kind of people who order the same thing, every time: vegetarian spring rolls and two bowls of chicken pho.  It is as rejuvenating as yoga. Yep.
author: Emliy H.

description: I come here whenever I am in the neighborhood and absolutely love it.  I have fond memories coming here with my father too, when he was getting treatments at UCSF.  Small and intimate setting, with really delicious food and Vietnamese beer.  Yum!
author: Julia B.

description: Great service. Very clean. But the food? Poorly priced and executed. Paid $4 for a single (very small) imperial roll that wasn't very crispy and was sort of chewy. It felt like it was mostly "roll" rather than "stuffing". The pho was weak -broth was bland and the noodles were overcooked. Also- I am unsure what kind of noodles they use but, it's a bit different from the traditional. $20 total for a large bowl of bland pho + 1 measly imperial roll + an iced coffee + tax + tip. Not so bad if it was really good but, it just wasn't so... Insult on injury. Oh well :(
author: Jen H.

description: Really good food at a decent price. The service was also very quick. I'd definitely come back!
author: alison c.

description:
After running errands in Pac Heights, I wanted to pick up dinner on the way home and after consulting my handy Yelp iPhone app, I found My Father's Kitchen. After skimming the reviews of the pho, I decided to play it safe and order two vermicelli bowls - one pork and one imperial roll - and also a side of imperial rolls. Hey! Don't judge! I love imperial rolls (cha gio)! 

- The cha gio were fried to perfection and super flavorful. 
- Both vermicelli bowls were perfect. I like how they put the grilled pork in the same bowl with the fish sauce to marinate. 

The next time around I decided to try the pho. The bf LOVED it! People wrote in their reviews that it's not as flavorful as other pho places since this is Northern Vietnamese cuisine. The best way to describe the pho broth here is CLEAN and there is absolutely nothing wrong with CLEAN pho! 

Now every time I come to Pac Heights to run errands I pick up take-out from My Father's Kitchen. Be sure to get their viet iced coffee as well. It isn't the super strong kind of iced coffee, but it is packed full of flavor. We love it!
author: Jen D.

description: Been here a couple of times now. The food taste very good and presented very well. A little pricey but you get your money's worth. The service is very fast and the lady that helped was very pleasant. The place is a small and cramp. You can bump other customers on your way to the tables placed  on the corner or wall. That is the reason for the minus 1. Still planning to come back here to taste their other products.
author: Lynette S.

description: Small portion and fru fru food for Vietnamese "home cooking".  Convenient if you're at Mt. Zion for an appointment.  Food is fresh, flavorful and ok.  Their menu is not the average pho joint, so don't go there thinking you can get a regular rice plate or noodle soup.  If you want a little classy Vietnamese style lunch - this is the place to go.
author: JJAMZ C.

description:
Best Ever Northern Vietnamese pho tái #8 on the menu:
It's beef rice noodle soup with rare 'eye of round' steak - I always order it 'on the side'.   The excellent broth is 'da bomb' with the freshest noodles.  
This is my favorite breakfast and you can find me here at 9:30 am.
author: Geri S.

description:
I brought my father here, and he was not amused.  In light of limited healthy offerings near UCSF Mt. Zion, this isn't bad.  Yes, the pho broth is too light.  However, people can't you taste it?  There's no MSG! And the broth isn't mostly made of fish sauce! (not saying the pho is good, which is really meh, just saying there's an absence of MSG)

That said, people who said "the imperial rolls and bun cha thit nuong are spot on" are on crack.  The imperials rolls are twice fried so it lacks a crispy interior.  The meats in the bun cha thit nuong are not grilled well enough and the fish sauce lacks a bold savory flavor.  Although, I will say that the imperial rolls are authentic.  Not only has the restaurant used the right stuffing, but the correct wrapper. 

Ultimately, the food here is catered to white people (sorry guys, I had to say it).  The food is watered down to suit the taste of the staff at the hospital.  

It's not a bad option for folks who work in the area, despite the obscene wait.   But I can't come back here for Vietnamese food.  It's overpriced for what it is and lacks strong execution.  Plus, my father has issued a stern warning that I'm never to bring him here again.
author: P L.

description: Great broth and flavors, expensive small portion for a large beef pho. Service was great and place is small and cute. If they had bigger portions I would go back.
author: Karen T.

description:
- food: fresh yet bland
- atmosphere: modern
- staff: nice 
- price: cheap

additional info:
- pho noodles were flat and thick
author: J. B.

description:
Pretty good little neighbourhood Vietnamese.   I probably wouldn't travel especially for this restaurant but if you are in the area it is a good option.

I had the imperial rolls and they were very tasty.  Cost $15.00 including t&t.  Service was friendly and it was a pleasant space.
author: Pig E.

description: I ordered my lunch here twice. Both were pretty good.  Their pho is decent and I don't taste so much MSG like other Vietnamese places. Price is Okay consider ing the location. Will definitely come back.
author: Wendy L.

description: Pho hits the spot. Simple and delicious
author: Melisaa D.

description:
Consistently yummy Pho Ga - light broth, not oily, wide noodles, pieces of white meat chicken are of good quality

Decent Papaya Salad - generous amount of shredded green papaya with fish sauce, but no hot spices added, no green beans, not muddled

Shrimp Spring Rolls - fresh and tasty with an interesting (in a good way) peanut sauce. They add something different to give it a creamier texture, but I can't put my finger on it.

I can't eat the Imperial Rolls, but I hear they are pretty good.
author: Jessica P.

description:
I really wanted this place to be good. Mediocre at best. I could tell you 10 other pho places that destroy this place. I like this place cause it's clean. That's all they have going for them. 

There are nine small tables in this restaurant. With 3 wait servers and still their service is horrible. I went there twice and he same thing happened. They are too busy conversing w each other,mother forget they have customers to service. Not once has any one ever come t me asking everything is alright. Not even once. I had to go and fetch my check from the long hair ,scruffy looking stoner guy who was busy making a sign for his tip jar!! Im being serious.

I'm an owner of a restaurant and I can't stress how important great service is. ESP when your food is mediocre
author: steve a.

description: Delicious Vietnameese coffee and young,  vibrant atmosphere. The waiter's are super nice and know a bunch about the food and portion sizes. I will definitely come back again as soon as possible. Location is nice too, just take the 38 from Downtown SF to Divisidero and walk a couple blocks and you are there!
author: Owen G.

description:
This restaurant mainly serves the nearby hospital staff/students/etc.

Probably reason for the higher prices for such bland broth!!

I ordered the Pho Ga and it came with very little chicken and some very bland broth. I was very surprised by it considering the kitchen seem to be filled with Vietnamese cooks and the owner herself is Vietnamese.

I know it's suppose to be Northern Vietnamese style Pho but Turtle Tower definitely has this place beat. I came once to try it out after reading an article about this place but super disappointed.

Definitely stars for the great decor, good jazz music, and cute server.

And no stars for the actual food.
author: Yvonne T.

description: I enjoyed a quick lunch today with pho ga...great noodles and broth.  Got out of there in less than 18 minutes.  When I arrived at my meeting, two people in the group had take-out from here...steaming bowls of soup (why did I hurry...I could have done the same).   Good eats!
author: Amelyn C.

description:
i usually order their grilled boneless chicken with satay sauce over rice and their spring rolls.  very tasty, their peanut sauce that comes with the spring rolls is amazing!  im glad that it's very close to my work.  

their staffs are very courteous and very respectful... the simple things like saying thank you, have a good day, what can i do for you, and they say this with a smile and with their attention to you... very important for a customer if you ask me :)

highly recommended
author: Rocky D.

description: One of my go-to spots for lunch. I'm addicted to their spring rolls and the peanut cream dipping sauce. I usually order it to go and the staff are always fast and friendly. I also order the 5 spice chicken and love that I can substitute vermicelli noodles instead of rice.
author: Rona V.

description:
I've only had the beef pho, and it was deliciously made in traditional northern style. Tastes very similar to how my family makes it and broth was as good as a 'not made by my mom or aunt' will get at a restaurant. I'm super critical of pho, so it's pretty amazing that I'm giving a good review.

Don't go here if you're used to/ looking for, typical msg ridden, overly salty, sugar enhanced pho. Don't go here if you enjoy warm hoisin water. Lesson to you hoisin lovers: Hoisin doesn't go in northern pho - it's an insult to the time and flavor of the broth.

Disclosure: BF brought me the surprise pho home delivery from here... but no, the sweet delivery has nothing to do with my good review of the pho. 

Looking forward to going back to try their other stuff. Review may or may not change after I actually visit the restaurant.
author: Lily H.

description:
Beautiful setting, but the seating a bit cramped. Food is delicious, I definitely would go back for LUNCH. Go before the crowd comes from the UCSF hospital area. 

Overall, if they maintain the great service and good food, it would be around for a while. Favorites? Soup dishes
author: Edgar M.

description: 5 stars for their super-friendly (what?!), crazy fast service. Also, really good prices (and they accept cc). 4 stars for food- which is probably more like 5 stars anywhere else, but I mean, this is San Francisco so the bar is pretty freaking high.
author: K P.

description:
I was killing time in the neighborhood because I was waiting for a friend being seen at Kaiser. I walked in to this place because i love Vietnamese food. I can't say much for this place though. The food was overpriced and not that good. I ordered an appetizer of imperial rolls, when my waitress delivered them to the table I noticed that there was only two imperials rolls cut in half with a bunch of greens. I asked the waitress if they always serve only two rolls (4 inches long)? She said no, there is four when we cut them in half. I said, "For $7.50, don't you think that's a little too steep?" She said, "I don't  fix the prices here, I just serve the food"  

If you're looking for good Vietnamese food, avoid this place like the plague. It is a rip-off and way over priced for mediocre food.
author: J D.

description: The best tasting pho broth in the city that does not require doctoring up like most low quality Vietnamese restaurants. Also the best tasting peanut sauce ever! Love my Father's Kitchen.
author: Katie K.

description: Delicious pho, vermicelli pork, and spring rolls. My kids eat the peanut sauce with a spoon. (The staff is always happy to give us extra.) Kind, generous service at this family-run place.
author: Marcella G.

description:
I've had this place once just because it's right across the street from my work and my coworkers go VERY often. The broth is bland without the beef taste and the noodles hard. 

Their menu is simple and springrolls are $5. They also serve Blue Bottle Coffee but I think almost all restaurants sell it nowadays...

Cute and clean place. I must say I am biased, coming from a Vietnamese/Chinese family to be comparing pho made by white folks when my momma can make it at home. Come here if it's your last resort on a cold/windy day in SF and you're craving soupy noodles regardless of its taste.
author: Rosanne L.

description: This place really does make comfort food. We all ordered the pho and we loved it. The staff was attentive and very friendly. We will definitely go back. We asked for one of our bowls to be vegetarian and they kindly accommodated us. Great food and great service. If you're in the mood for good food then this your place!
author: Maria A.

description: It's not like the place I'm the Richmond but it's pretty damn yummy. Service  is great and since when is $8 for pho expensive? I think people just like to hate. I like that there's finally a decent pho place in my neighborhood.
author: Claire D.

description:
Wow looking forward to another bowl of pho on a nice 'summer' San Francisco day. 

I remembered how great the pho was. I was disappointed. The broth was bland....really bland. What happened?! 

My friends had the non-pho dishes and they liked their food. Maybe I should skip the pho and go for the rice dishes. So sad to give it 2 stars now.
author: Molly T.

description: I don't know, I've read the negative reviews but was near there and very hungry, so I stopped in and had a split soup (chicken pho) and a papaya salad. The serving was pretty big for the soup (a Small) and it was freaking delicious! The salad, though small at a half-portion was really good, as well.  Attentive and friendly/prompt service.  The soup/salad option wasn't even on the menu but the waitress read my mind and suggested it.  Bravo.  It's close to home and I frequently jones for pho, so I'll definitely be back.
author: David V.

description: Tastes like noodles in water; the soup is not even soup tbh. To foreigners of Vietnamese culture and authentic pho, it may seem good. But with someone that has grown up with Vietnamese food, man oh man--I just can't even think of coming back here. The portions of the noodles and meat were not plentiful. $10 when I can get quality pho for $7.50 in an Asian neighborhood. The interior looks nice but that doesn't make up for the food quality, which is poor.
author: Natalie Charlotte W.

description: I love this place I can neve find good food like this in sj  I go all the way to sf
author: Jovannah N.

description:
Since this place caters to the UCSF Mt Zion crowd, it is often closed when the rest of the world gets off work, but I was fortunate enough to get there before its 7pm closing time today. It definitely wins the first impression contest, neat, clean, relaxed for a casual meal.

To the food. The ch giò (fried spring rolls) was a pleasant surprise, very flavorful while keeping the grease to a really bare minimum, what treat. The unbelievable $7.50 pricetag for just 4 pieces, however, will sober you up quickly! After that, we tried both versions available of ph bò and, while initially very simple and healthy-tasting, the lack of salt and extra herbs like basil,mint or cilantro eventually made the experience very bland. Also priced at $7.50, this is some expensive bland beef soup! Well, at least I feel healthier and not so thirsty now!
author: Paolo D.

description:
My Father's Kitchen's pho is Northern Vietnamese. Which means you're not going to get the extra stuff like bean sprouts, basil, hoisin sauce, and all that junk--although it does come with chili and lime. The rice noodles flat and thicker than the regular Saigon style pho that folks are normally used to. I've never had Northern Vietnamese pho until I came here. And I'm a bit torn on this review, because I don't know if it's because I'm just less of a fan of that particular style of pho, or if it really is the restaurant itself.

The noodles were great. Chewy, thick, warm, and actually better than Saigon style pho. It's also ridiculously filling. The broth was... meh. It's delicate, but it wasn't very meaty or seasoned. And again, not sure if that's the style or the restaurant. Cuts of meat were okay. Few slices here and there. Nothing spectacular. And if you like the weird funky stuff like tendon and tripe (or even meatballs), you won't find that here.

They're really busy and understaffed at lunch, so the staff can be a bit terse with you. I get it, it's not personal.
author: Desdemona C.

description: Came here for lunch the other day and enjoyed some blue bottle coffee and the ga satay. Had a nice little zing but not too spicy, as it was tempered by the peanut sauce and rice. Yeah, I'm a spice wuss.
author: Dan B.

description:
*Not a Pretentious PHO Review*

Ahem...

Know what I don't know shit about peoples?  I'll fucking tell you that I know a hell of alot about some shit, and even more shit about other shit, but I dunno jack shit about (yeah you guessed it motherfucker) PHO.  What I do know is that I can be really lazy when I'm not feeling good, and that I like to eat fucktons of motherfucking PHO when this shit happens yo.  And there ain't no closer place to get some motherfuckin' PHO near my house cept' here, and thank fucking god this shit opened man, because I think they'll do real well and shit located up in this piece.  Hells yeah fucker.

I liked it alot.  Maybe not as much as PPQ and shit, but you know, it's pretty bomb dude. 

:/
author: Karen K.

description:
Very clean, quiet, and cute. Which is nice, but not exactly what I'm used to when it comes to Vietnamese restaurants. Usually good Pho places are always packed and a bit chaotic and messy. I'm also used to a bigger menu. The menu is only one page, and there are no desserts/a variety of exotic drinks. And the first thing I noticed was that it's pretty expensive compared to most other places.

The Pho was okay. Not amazing, but not bad. It was good enough to satisfy me. A bit bland, but I fixed that with lots and lots of sriracha, hoisin, and lemon.

I probably wouldn't return. There are better and cheaper restaurants. I just felt like this restaurant wasn't authentic.
author: Kayla I.

description: I usually order to go partly becuase this restaurant is pretty small. Their pho is pretty good, but a bit on the pricey side, in my opinion. I usually ask for extra noodles for days i'm super hungry. Staff is friendly,but one guy keeps calling me "m'am" which makes me feel old.
author: Christy Y.

description:
