Across the street from UCSF Hospital is a quaint, cozy, mom and pop restaurant called My Father's Kitchen.  Knowing that I personally do not like Northern Vietnamese cuisine, I still needed to try it.  Referred by Genevieve Y., I drove myself over here today to check it out.

The staff aren't fully trained yet, so the service will be a little slow.  The kitchen, on the other hand, is on que and ready to rock and roll.  This restaurant's identity is right in between Turtle Tower and Slanted door.  It's not a hole in a wall and it's not exactly a fine dining establishment..............It's right in between,

We ordered the the crab meat Imperial roll (7.95) and 2 small bowls of Pho Dac biet (6.95).  The roll was good. Crunchy, tasty, and fried well.  The pho............what can you expect from Northern Vietnam.  Very bland, simple, earthy, and good.  They have a great concept with the blue mountain drip coffee and the pastry in the front.  I think if ran correctly, the coffee should yield a higher return.  Menu is very simple.  One page with room to spare.

This place will work because they actually need a place like this here.  It's healthy, fresh, and the owner is very friendly.
author: jason g.

description: I could live with $10 pho if it weren't dishwater gray and bland.  As another reviewer observed, imperial rolls were really, excessively chewy and not that good.  With all the great Vietnamese choices in SF why bother?  Service is good and the space is crowded, minimalist but not unpleasant.  I just wish they served better food.
author: Ben L.

description:
On a brisk cloudy day, pho is always a perfect solution to warm up your insides. Nothing better than homemade broth slow cooked over night and rice noodles that slither down with bites of basil, mint, bean sprouts, and meat of choice (or tofu for veggie lovers). Its the way you prepare the soup with all these fixings and sauces (chili + hoisin) with a squeeze of lime that make this mouth watering noodle soup so simple yet delicious. 

Having that said, My Father's Kitchen owner must have used their non-Vietnamese father's recipe. The broth is bland/flavorless and might as well been 1 part can of chicken broth and 2 parts boiled water. The noodles were fine and the veggies were fresh. But come on.. put a little bit more effort if I'm going to support your $7 pho, instead of some other local joint in Little Saigon (not to say SF has aplethora of pho restaurants). 

I must admit this place has a nice clean contemporary ambiance: dark wooden tables, warm colored walls, and Blue Bottle drip coffee. Just not enough to sway me to give them a second chance until they step it up a notch.
author: sally y.

description:
The soups were good, but there were limited options beyond this. The ambience was not as cozy as I wished it was to enjoy a warm bowl of pho. 
The food just didn't wow me, although the service was friendly.
author: Rebecca S.

description: I was pretty disappointed by this location. The mango salad we had for an appetizer was yummy but the rice noodle soup (I got pho ga) was pretty disappointing. I seemed to have a lot of chicken skin in my soup and it just was not appetizing. There are better pho locations close-by that I would recommend over this location.
author: Megan T.

description:
UPDATE: I am upping my review since I was ignorant in knowing this is Northern style cuisine and I'm used to Souther style. Sorry My Father's Kitchen. Blame my original low review on ignorance.

So a friend calls me up and asks me if I want to try that new pho place in the neighborhood. I love pho so the thought of having a good pho restaurant in the hood excites me very much.

I get there and right away I can tell it's not your traditional pho restaurant. Just a little too clean in here. Too many non-asians in here. White people serving the food. These are clear signs this is not your traditional pho restaurant.

But whatever. I sit down and order the cha gio (imperial rolls) which is the staple app for Vietnamese restaurants and try to order the pho with everything in it (even though they didn't have tendon or the beef balls) but they were out of flank steak. OK whatevers. Cha gio was good. Pho comes out and it's the thick wide noodles. Not the traditional vermicelli style I like. Broth is just ok. Wish it was more flavorful. Meat is good. So then we ask for bean sprouts and basil. They don't have bean sprouts. Really? You serve pho but no bean sprouts. Then they bring us a plate of mint. Not basil. Mint. And no hoisin sauce on the table. Service was a little frantic as we were helped by three somewhat confused servers.

OK, I realize they're trying to do something different here. I realize they're not trying to be like every other traditional pho restaurant. And they're definitely trying to cater to a different audience. Unfortunately I'm not part of that different audience. I like my pho the traditional way. And get some servers that know the difference between basil and mint. Basil will certainly not have the minty smell...you know...like mint does.
author: David C.

description:
while waiting for the 24 on a few occasions, i've peered through the window to see a few vases full of bamboo and a more open and inviting interior compared to the once dreary and drab cool island cafe.  

alexandra n. invited me to lunch on their grand opening day, and i was pretty excited to try out a new restaurant that was nearby.  at a little after 1pm, i arrived first and caught the tail end of my father's kitchen being subjected to the clamor and commotion of a mostly ucsf employee lunch hour.  

12 dark, wooden tables and chairs were surrounded by what seemed to be gifts given for their grand opening.  vases full of lovely floral arrangements were sprinkled throughout the space.  i watched blue bottle coffee delightfully drip into a few cups and steaming bowls of pho make their entrance onto the restaurant floor.  

while it did take a bit to be greeted and seated, i can't fault them as it was their first day in business.  tracy, my father's kitchen's daughter, was (a temporary) one of two that comprised the waitstaff.  

'what makes the 'chicken rice noodle soup special' special?' i asked.  
'it's a traditional pho that has chicken eggs and liver in it,' she replied pleasantly.

while i was never a fan of liver during my childhood, i've found that it's grown on me.  ...plus, who can say no to eggs??

the small bowl ($7.50) was quite bigger than i thought.  the noodles were a bit slippery, so alexandra and i embraced a bastardized version of eating pho and employed a fork.  hah.  i would've preferred the chicken eggs to be a little softer and the chicken to be cooked a tiny bit longer, but i enjoyed the overall taste.  it was a good value, considering that all items on the menu are tax inclusive, and that both alexandra and i had leftovers.  ....ok, that's not saying much for me, but if ms. ginger had leftovers, then i'd say that's quite a feat.

tracy was very kind and apologetic for the minor mishaps that occurred during our lunch (being given our neighbor's order), but we reassured her that it was no problem at all, given that it was their first day.  ...added to that, waitressing isn't even tracy's full time job, and our order came out one minute after the mix up.  she even gave us a free chocolate chip cookie as a peace offering.  soft batch too!  thanks tracy!!

i'm definitely coming back, and hopefully, i'll be more adept w/chopsticks and slippery noodles.

(note that the hours are monday-friday, 8am-5pm.)

**update:  i guess they've changed the hours since ginger and i were here.  per their website, it's open from mon-sat, 8-5.
author: Ting A.

description:
On gloomy, dark and foggy summer days on Divis, when everyone else is enjoying summer food staples, I on the other hand have worked up quite the appetite for a big bowl of soup.  Now if I worked down the street from Soop in Berkeley, I'd be there in a heartbeat.  But with a bridge toll and 16 miles between us, when I crave soup during the lunching hour, I get pho.  I've been to this place twice now and it's an interesting place, definitely not a hole in the wall Asian restaurant.  The inside is very clean, and Pottery Barn-ish.  The servers are nice, and are ... gasp, not Asian?  This is definitely not your typical pho place.  I think they hit the "modern Vietnamese" theme spot on.  

As for the pho?  Prices are decent - $7-$8 for a small pot of pho ... which in my opinion, is not very small.  The pho stock is not too greasy or heavy (no big oil globs here!) which is a plus but it also means that it can be very bland.  The chicken and steak are definitely of higher quality here than at your typical pho place but the chicken was served a little overcooked and the meat was bland too.  I think they definitely have a cool concept going on here and with a little more improvements with upping the flavor quotient on the food, this could be a regular on those gloomy summer days on Divis (which are many).
author: Jean A.

description: The food and service was great and their Vietnamese coffee was probably the best I had yet. A little cramped inside so eating in might get a little annoying during  lunch/dinner rush. I rarely ever find myself in this part of town but I'd certainly come back if given the chance.
author: Danny K.

description:
2.5 stars rounded up to 3 for serving Blue Bottle coffee.

I tried the Pho Ga, Pho Bo, and imperial rolls. Unfortunately only the imperial rolls were good. Neither of the soups' broth had enough essence of chicken or beef. Noodles were the fresh wide silky variety and meats were nice and moist. But the broths were not up to my standard. They tasted like they were made with wonton soup base. 

Also, no garnishes here. No basil, bean sprouts, jalapenos or lime. I had to add fish sauce to the broth.

I prefer Turtle Tower and Quan Bac for northern style Pho.
author: Derrick V.

description: I gave this place two tries, since it's so close to my work.  It is the blandest pho ever.  There is absolutely nothing to it and no amount of sriracha can save it.  However, I do still come here when I have a hankering for spring rolls.  They're standard though.  I've never had a fresh spring roll I didn't like, because it is literally the same thing everywhere you go.  People rave about the peanut sauce here, but I hate peanuts, so I can't comment on it.  I always just have some soy & sriracha with my rolls.  If you want pho, though...go elsewhere.
author: Shannon B.

description: Wanted this to be good, but the overwhelming amount of MSG in pho was a HUGE turn off...service was nice, interior was good, but just couldn't get over the MSG factor in the food!!
author: Richard D.

description:
I can see why this place doesn't get good reviews.

I got the chicken rice noodle pho.  The chicken was tough and the soup was bland.

I also got the spring rolls -- 2 rolls for $7.50?  The guy at the counter said a lot of people complain about how high the price is for spring rolls and he says it's because they use fresh crab meat inside.  I looked on the inside and couldn't tell that there was any crab in there -- my conclusion: definitely overpriced.

Overall conclusion:  wouldn't return unless I was in a bind.
author: Ava C.

description: I love this place! I've been coming here regularly since they opened. I'm not a big fan of pho so that's not what I come here for. I love blue bottle coffee and the staff is friendly and always remembers me. Nice clean bathroom, and you can always get a table before 12. After 12 there can be a wait, but it's usually not too bad. Maybe its the amazing peanut sauce they come with, but i find the vegetarian spring rolls are better here than at Slanted Door. My favorite is the #10 Satay chicken although a lot of people prefer the 5 spice chicken.  I find the food extremely consistent and inexpensive compared to the pricey sandwiches next door from Pete's Deli or the disgusting hospital cafeteria across the street. I think this is a 4-star joint and will continue to patronize!
author: Kelley S.

description:
Delicious and authentic Pho made with real homemade stock!  Not the standard SF cheap, quickly prepared, overly spiced, MSG laden pho!  

I spent 2 weeks in Vietnam last year...this is the closest I have found in SF.  The subtle flavors are dead on.  I close my eyes when eating the pho and I'm back in Hanoi.

FYI- they make their own Imperial roll wrappers from scratch.  Almost everywhere else in town uses generic rice paper wrappers from Costco.  They are delicious!

Take what I say with a grain of salt because I am addicted.
author: Kevin D.

description:
I have been recuperating after a long weekend out with friends visiting from Brasil and London.  Only been eating one meal a day. Not because I am trying to starve myself before my vacation soon, but just been drinking more alcohol than anything. I forget to eat!

My first real meal for the day came from this place I found as I was walking back from a massage not too far from this place. I found it to be very 'clean' for an Asian eatery (if you know what I mean!!) The only other places I know that are this clean and unique are Anna Mandera & Tommy Toys! As I looked at the menu by the window, I quickly glanced at the guy eating phô by it and noticed he had just finished the whole thing! I peaked to see what kind of action I was going to get in. I saw an Asian lady resting her one leg on a seat, some Pac Heights moms that just picked their kids from school, and some edgy dudes from the block! I said to myself "OK" let me try this place..I'm a sucker for Vietnamese food. 

At first, the waitress is also the hostess. Basically, it's a one person place. She was taking an order from a dude. As I looked around the place, the decor reminds me that of Chilango on Church St. I waited patiently for her to say hello. Five minutes later, she notices I'm standing right there. I asked for a table, she said "anywhere". I sat down and immediately grabbed a menu. Without a miss, I always make sure they have fresh spring rolls. As I skimmed through the menu really quickly, it's a very plain and simple menu. Not too many options. I wished they had shaken beef as part of their menu. It's one of my favorite dishes. Where's the beef!!!????

So, I ended ordering the spring rolls and the five spice chicken with vermicelli noodles. I did notice that the prices are more expensive than other Vietnamese places. But I was already there. 

My impression of the spring rolls, very clean!!! I will say this, I have tried this appetizer in every Vietnamese restaurant I can think of. I have NEVER EVER tried a peanut sauce like that! It blew my mind how good it was. It was very creamy and flavorful. The peanut sauce in other places I guess use stale peanuts or recycled from other tables. YES! I said it! Don't act coy on me!!!! If you just dip dip, you know they use it over!

As far as the five spice chicken vermicelli plate. It was very well presented. The noodles were on the side along with some greens. A lot of mint and basil...Didn't know what to do with that much. The chicken and sausage had a lot of flavor. I couldn't complain.

Overall, I see that a lot of Yelpers did not have a good experience with the phô. My spring rolls and chicken was good. Although I only gave them 3 stars, people who know me know that I rate these places on service  more so than the food. Yes, the food has to be consistent, but you're gonna eat it anyways!!! But service is what makes it count.

Will I come back? Yes, of course! My massage place is just down the corner. It might be a Monday routine!
author: T M.

description: I was very disappointed with the food at this restaurant.  I always love trying out Vietnamese restaurants and I was curious about this place, having passed by it countless times.  For the price of $14, my lunch special (vegetarian) included spring rolls that tasted like burned rubber.  I could barely swallow them and don't think they actually contained any vegetables at all.  Then, the only other food that came with the mediocre noodles was tasteless grass - there were no other vegetables or anything edible that would come with a vegetarian meal.   I think that this place has an impressive outward facade, but sadly, is just yet another place that demonstrates that we should not judge a book by its cover.  Note: I felt badly giving one star because the service was good.
author: Kate S.

description:
Came here for brunch-nothing sets your day up like a Vietnamese coffee.  I had never had one before, and was pleasantly surprised at the flavor.  It's essentially really strong coffee with a sweetened condensed milk layer.  Absolutely going to jazz you up the rest of the day.

As for the meal, I shared the bún ch tht nng-the marinated grilled pork and meatballs served with fresh herbs, rice vermicelli, and fish sauce.  it was definitely enough food for two fairly hungry people.  The flavor was great and the meatballs were done just right.  A friend had the beef pho and said it was above average.

The atmosphere is really modern and it wasn't too crowded.
author: AJ L.

description: I love my local pho spot. Simple but delicious comfort food. I nearly always order the chicken pho and fresh spring rolls, which are a sizeable appetizer.
author: Della H.

description:
Very limited menu selection.  Pho is ok but they only have the 'normal meats'- no tripe or tendon, which are my favorites.  Vermicilli dishes are good but wayyyy overpriced at around $12.

Basically, it's a kitschy little place in a 'fancy' part of town that's way overpriced but serves decent food.  Just don't go in expecting truly authentic Vietnamese food.  And at $6.50 for 2 spring rolls, it was just meh.  

Too bad this city lacks good authentic Vietnamese unless you go to Little Vietnam which is freakin ghetto in the Tenderloin and made me super-nervous just parking my car and going inside to get takeout.  Sigh.
author: Maxine S.

description: Thought this place rocked.  Have Pho on a regular basis. Such a clean and healthy meal. This place feels extra clean and takes a minimalistic attitude.  Other places give you the cilantro, basil, been sprouts, this place does not.  I like that stuff but the overall dish was not compromised.  Just sayin' it is a different prep than any other place and the servings were huge.  Delicious. Wonderful.  Very minimal and nice.  Loved it!  Will go back.
author: Elisa B.

description:
Pros
nice atmosphere
clean restaurant
blue bottle coffee a plus 
decent prices regarding pho I guess kinda
only pho in the west add nopa 
server  is polite when taking order 
constanty refilling water

Cons

oily broth 

no vegetarian pho options

chicken pieces are a bit shady sometimes 

beef not served on the side as an option...so it tends to be overcooked on arrival to table

not actual rice noodles served and they are overcooked

felt rushed by server 

small portions

End Result 
probally won't cone back unless I am in the neighborhood and starving
author: Nikola B.

description:
My Father's Kitchen was a disappointment- there was nothing traditional about it.  

We ordered:
veggie spring rolls with peanut sauce
chicken pho
beef pho
tai ice tea

We got the spring rolls pretty quickly- but we thought that they were bland, even with the peanut sauce.  The waiter asked how it was when we were finished and my very honest boy friend said 'blan'... the waiter looked puzzled and said 'really?' and walked away.

The pho just tasted like chicken.. there was not much offered to us to put in our pho- like in traditional restaurants...  we doused ours with a decent amount of saracha, but that didn't even do the trick. Very disappointing.

The one thing we LOVEd with the tai iced tea- sooo yummy

Overall, the place is cute, the people are nice- but we will not be returning.  We would rather find a traditional pho restaurant in the city, then eat at a trendy place.
author: Sherri B.

description:
My Father's Kitchen really falls between a 2 and a 3. The thing is this place is totally serviceable - you know, it would do in a pinch, especially considering the dearth of Vietnamese in the neighborhood. But, honestly, when you've got places like Tu Lan or Pho Huynh Hiep 2, My Father's Kitchen's food is a poor facsimile. 

There are a few good things:
It's reasonably priced. The ph bò c bit (pho with rare eye of round steak, brisket, and flank) was only $8.50, and the bún ch tht nng (marinated grilled pork and meatballs with vermicelli) was $11. Also, the decor's far nicer than either of the two places mentioned above. The service was friendly.

All in all, I might come back, but only if I'm really craving pho and I don't want to go too far.
author: Car C.

description:
Top notch pho and vietnamese coffee made with Blue Bottle. 

Really nice people and crowd.

The restaurant has a nice style too. Kind of Restoration Hardware.

Only thing they do wrong is not being open for dinner.

Stop in for tasty pastries and coffee in the morning starting at 8:30 too. (when pastries usually arrive)
author: Christopher F.

description: I come here almost every other Tuesday for lunch. The staff here is very friendly and the pho here is much better than most places. The broth is very flavorful for each of the different types of soup and the crispy imperial rolls is a must have.
author: anthony f.

description: I don't understand why this restaurant currently has such a high star rating. I had read great reviews of the food and couldn't wait to try it. Sadly, it was an all-around disappointing dining experience. The chicken satay was SUPER greasy and lacked flavor. The peanut sauce was weak. My father got some rolls and was equally disappointed. What can I say? Sometimes restaurants don't live up to their hype.
author: Erin W.

description:
Ate here while waiting for an MRI at UCSF around the corner. 

The room is furnished w/modern tables and warmly painted walls, but the tables are very small and crowded together.

Had a steak pho (as I normally do) but it was served with an unusual flat rice noodle that I've never been served before w/pho.  Asked if they made it but was told that they bought it.  They also did not serve the normal plate of condiments -- basil, bean sprouts, lime and jalepeno pepper slices..  Only got lime and jalapeno slices, which I thought was "cheap" considering that a bowl of pho here costs a little more than at other Vietnamese restaurants that I've been to.

The pho was just ok.  There wasn't that much steak and there weren't that many noodles.  So, all in all, I'd have to say that it wasn't that "bad" but I've  definitely experienced better.  Hence, the 2 star rating.  

Don't think I'll eat here again and, if I'm in the area for lunch again, I would probably choose to eat at the Sugar Bowl in the Kaiser bldg on Geary instead, which isn't anything to write home about but at least gives you a better value for your $.
author: Martin C.

description:
This review concerns only the Pho and Vietnamese Coffee.

Both were just not Vietnamese. The Pho was a watery soup that tasted like not much. I had the Pho Tai, which is raw beef. The beef actually tasted pretty good, but maybe that's only because the broth was so tasteless.

They make northern style Pho, so wider and fewer noodles and just lime (lemon in this case) and chiles instead of the fancier southern style Pho.

I'd prefer Turtle Tower for northern style Pho any time, and Pho 2000 is way better than this place.
author: X O.

description: I ate here today for the first time. It was pretty darn good! a bit pricey but the pho was amazing. The broth was really good, I ordered to go and they were quick. the spring rolls were expensive for two pieces but they were good and the sauce was good. I'm glad I ordered a small soup, could barely finish that. I will be back for sure!
author: Anna S.

description: This review is based solely on the spring rolls. Best I've ever had. Period!
author: elizabeth r.

description: I was in the neighborhood and noticed that this place serves blue bottle coffee.  score, right? WRONG!  So I go in and ask the hippie at the counter if they serve coffee to go (so I can take it to the hospital waiting room), he says, "yes, large or small."  I respond politely asking, "how big is a small?"  To which he points to what appears to be a ceramic bowl (the size of one pho would be served in) up a shelf, saying to go, "is the same size."  Weird but it's blue bottle so say ok.  Then he tells me the price...$8.13!!  I said no way and walked out.  I live about .5 km from the hayes kiosk where a cup is $3.25, not sure why they're selling it a at 2.5x markup.
author: brion p.

description:
Went here twice in a week.  Both times we had the spring rolls and papaya salad, both so fresh and flavorful.  We also tried the chicken Pho and it was different then I've had in the past, but still very yummy. The imperial rolls were also delicious.  

Just writing this review makes me want to go back!
author: Tamz O.

description:
Disclaimer: I'm a DIE-HARD Turtle Tower fan and will drive 30 minutes in the rain if I had to get a fix!  

My brother lives in the area so we decided to check this place out and see how it compares to TT.

The broth and chicken here is decent but the noodles are rubbery and nothing like the fresh noodles at TT.  Its a poor imitation of Northern Style Pho.  But I must say the spring rolls were pretty good and authentic.

The decor is modern and the restaurant is clean but the pho doesn't do it for me.

So, I will continue to enjoy my TT pho and probably skip My Father's Kitchen!
author: Lucy K.

description: We were looking for Pho on this cold eve. This place really hit the spot. The service was great, super friendly and we were seated right away at 6ish on a Friday eve. The Pho was really good. Good portions, highly recommended.
author: Andrew B.

description: this place is just ok if you are realllly craving some pho and reallllllllly need to have some for lunch. its the only pho spot by my job so yeah.
author: wendy h.

description: I don't know, I like this place. I never get the Pho though, so maybe that is the issue? I really like the chicken satay a lot, sometimes I find myself craving it. The sauce is delish, and they serve it with basil, mint and lettuce. They have awesome coffee, and real nice staff. They are always very cool to me when I come in with a kiddo in tow. It is affordable as well. In a dream world, they would open for dinner (as of right now it is only a lunch spot) and perhaps get a little more variety on the menu. Maybe some Vietnamese sandwiches? A little shaking beef? I'd vote for that.
author: Natalie D.

description: Was at a doctor appt at Mt. Zion and walked past it.  When we were done I needed some lunch so we checked it out...very tasty.  Cute inside, a nice, diverse choice for that neighborhood (there aren't enough good lunch spots over there if you work near there).  I enjoyed the chicken Bun, but it's not your typical Vietnamese fare (e.g. they don't have all the side "extras" like bean sprouts, lime, peppers, etc) so be prepared for that.
author: Nancy K.

description:
I tried out this place a few days ago, because it's the newest and closest Vietnamese restaurant from me.  Walking into the restaurant, I was happy with the simple and clean decor.  I was excited to try the chicken noodle soup special......especially, because it has the intestines.  

I started with the Vietnamese iced coffee.  The waitress we had brought one with condense milk, after asking me twice what I wanted.  I got my pho and it was a bit more oily than what i am used to.  It tasted okay, not bad, but not good either.  Also, I'm sad that there was no hoisin sauce.  It would have tasted better if i was able to have it to dip my meat with.  I understand that it is northern style pho, but it would benefit the restaurant more if customers were given that option.  I'm pretty sure there is hoisin somewhere in the back of the kitchen.  I tried asking for it, but the server had no idea what hoisin sauce is.

As for the service....I guess you can't blame people who never served.  As for business owners, I suggest hiring servers with actual serving experience.  The server I got looked completely lost and clueless.  She barely speaks any English.  While I was there, I saw one table trying to get the servers' attention for a few times and was completely ignored.  One of the girls ended up going up to the counter.  Another table tried to waved someone down for their check for about 10 minutes and was not acknowledged until a waiting customer told the guy at the counter.  It is important for a new restaurant to well staffed....especially since your servers are the face of the restaurant.  They should be able to multi-tasks and be alert.  However, what I saw was confusion and the waitresses getting in each others way.
author: Mai-Tam N.

description:
I just got back from eating at this Vietnamese Comfort food-style restaurant.  I loved it!  As a fan of NO msg and healthier options to dining out (I am a cancer survivor) I really appreciated that the pho didn't have any msg or other additives.  I had the number 7 large and it was very good!  It was filling too- I couldn't finish it.  But I always get the large size with phos  since I love soup.  Anyways, the fresh spring rolls are good too.  I don't like peanuts in general but I did try the peanut sauce that came with the spring rolls and it tasted very clean with no unnecessary additives.  The ONLY reason I didn't give it five stars is because although it's in an ideal location (across the street from UCSF on Divisadero) for hospital employees etc. - that's exactly why I didn't like the location.  It was super crowded and we had to wait for a table.  The parking was tough too.  For me, pho is a no fuss no muss comfort food so when I go to eat pho, I go to RELAX and a neighborhood pho place usually makes me feel that way.  But this place was crowded and I almost felt under-dressed b/c I was wearing sweats and a cap with minimal makeup (hey even models have days off).  But overall WONDERFUL four stars!  Oh, and the blue bottle drip coffee was out of this world!

I just got back from NYC and when I found out that there are no pho restaurants there - or at least any good ones- I feel more blessed than ever to be a San Franciscan.  I love the food in this wonderful, vibrant, and beautiful city I call home.

My Father's Kitchen is a great find for pho lovers.  See you there!
author: Esther H.

description: We were greeted with a super friendly guy when we arrived starting the experience off right. Ordered the chicken pho and 5spice chicken dish along with some blue bottle coffee. Everything was delicious,  the atmosphere was modern yet cozy, and the staff super friendly! I will definitely be returning.
author: Brittany P.

description:
First, a disclaimer: I'm from Houston, and I've grown up with fabulous, flavorful, authentic pho that the large Vietnamese population provides and demands in that city. Now that I live here, I'm on the lookout for the most flavorful broth and i can get and the tenderest meat I can find.  While this isn't the best pho I've ever had, it was really, really quite nice: I liked the generous portion of noodles, I thought the quality of the beef cuts was high, and I thought the spices were just right. I tend to like a lot of heat, so I dosed the broth with fish sauce and sriracha, but it didn't need it: this was really tasty stuff.  Since the broth is critical--and, to some, the whole point--I was thrilled to eat here. I also love that they have the shredded papaya salad on the menu; that's one of my favorite dishes, and I will certainly have it next time I'm in the area.

This was a nice place to grab lunch on a chilly summer SF day. The service was attentive and cheerful in spite of the lunch rush, and the prices were fair. Totally worth a weekday lunch.
author: Tricia K.

description:
I went here  for lunch while going to a class at UCSF.   It is nice and clean.  The service was prompt and  courteous.  The environment was cool and relaxed.

However, the food was terrible.  I looove Vietnamese, but this was bland and over priced.  The green papaya salad was the tastiest thing on the menu, but still lacked the pop of the fish sauce. I can make better myself.

The pho was awful.  No mung beans, no lemon,   cilantro was brought to me on request.  Evidently this is a Northern style and I am  used to a Southern style, or was that vice versa.  Either way, it was not to my tastes.  The noodles were the thicker  udon style, which combined with bland broth ( my companions charitably called it "clean tasting")  left me not finishing the bowl, a rarity I assure you.

My husband's imperial rolls over vermicelli and  BBQ pork was better, but still mediocre.

there are too many good places to eat to  go back here.  I do like the blue bottle coffee offering . maybe if I was going for coffee rather than food I would come back.  There are too many good places on the Divis strip to waste time with mediocre food.
author: maia j.

description:
I love Vietnamese, and this was such a disappointment. Fresh spring rolls are always my go-to starter, but these were tasteless and boring.  The sauce was equally unimpressive - tasted like watered down peanut butter.  

This place is overpriced and lacks in authenticity.  If you are craving Vietnamese, head to the Inner Richmond district. 

2 stars for food, 1 star for the blue bottle coffee (which was easily the highlight of the meal)
author: Malorie E.

description:
Amazing. Delicious. Haunting flavors & kind wait staff.

The Pho is unlike any other I have tasted, so even though I am no expert on authenticity I can understand what other Yelpers are saying. To me, it was astonishing. 

The spring rolls were tasty but the peanut sauce was weird, and this time the novelty was not something I liked. I mixed siracha fish sauce lemon and jalepeno together instead and loved that. 

I will certainly go back.
author: Keeva L.

description: Awesome, home cooked Vietnamese.  Really quality.  Pho and both style of spring rolls were spot on and super fresh.  Not to mention the place is super clean.
author: Wilson B.

description: Okay in a pinch, but definitely no where near the best pho. Sizes (at least to-go) are inconsistent. Co-worker ordered a large, and I ordered a small, and they were exactly the same amount in the broth and noodle containers. Noodles are larger than usual pho noodles, thus more watery and bland. They use lemons instead of limes, do not include sprouts, mint, or basil. There is a little bit of cilantro, but the chicken pho was very watered down. Papaya salad had no spice, tasted more sweet than spicy. Prices were not cheap compared to other places. If you want large portions and more flavor, head to Yummy Yummy.
author: Christine C.

description:
Does any restaurant in San Francisco serve decent pho without MSG? I haven't found one, but I keep searching, because several people in my work group have serious reactions to MSG and absolutely cannot eat it, as in, zero amount.

(I realize there are many people who doubt that the "Chinese restaurant syndrome" is real; I also realize that the syndrome has not been scientifically proven. That said, I would refer doubters to the work of such cutting-edge doctors as Timothy Smith MD of Sebastopol, one of the best physicians and health researchers in the U.S. today, author of "Renewal" [1998], who, on pps. 142-143 of that book, lays out a solid case against this junk that inundates our food. [Among other things, Smith says that a pregnant woman shouldn't touch MSG with a 10-foot-pole; the risk of birth defects is too high.] I would also refer doubters to the tales of explosive diarrhea, headache, numbness and nausea told by members of my work group.)

So, anyway, in my never-ending quest to find a decent pho place with no MSG I called My Father's Kitchen and spoke to Kelly, a server. I asked, "Does your pho have MSG?" She replied with great enthusiasm, "No!"

"Absolutely none?" "None!" "You're 100 percent sure?" "110 percent!"

I was ecstatic! My work group had scheduled an evening session for later that week and I had promised I would bring pho with no MSG. Everyone in my group was jazzed. This was an extremely important planning meeting; we had a lot of work to do; we needed the evening to go well; we had scheduled the meeting to the minute; great pho with no MSG would contribute significantly to our success.

I made a trek to My Father's, walked in, and asked the guy behind the counter, "You don't have any MSG in your pho, right? Kelly told me that. I'm really happy about that!" Answer: "Well, we do have MSG. We don't actually ADD any but there's some in there." I wasn't clear how this worked - I gathered it had to do with the ingredients that they got from a supplier, perhaps? - in any event, I was crushed. Even a tiny amount is a no-go for people who are sensitive to it. My work group was meeting in 15 minutes, they were waiting for their pho. (I will add, two women in my group are pregnant.)

I ordered some pho for the four people in my group who are OK with MSG and resigned myself to finding some other kind of food someplace else for the other four people - I had no idea where to look in that neighborhood - but, well, I'd find someplace eventually, which would cause me to be late and keep everyone waiting. Kelly came over while I was waiting. She had been misinformed by restaurant management. She apologized, kind of. I expressed my concerns in frank terms. She replied, "You don't need to be upset! It's OK! It's OK!" Well, no, it was not OK, no matter how much Kelly wished it be OK. My work group's session, our most important meeting of the month, had been seriously messed up by her failure to be a professional about her work, by her failure to learn what was in the food she served people, which I take to be a primary responsibility of a good waitperson who's actually interested in helping people enjoy their food and preserve their health. (How many people, I wonder, has she managed to lead astray on this topic? How many pregnant women? I shudder to think.)

I suggested to the guy behind the counter that I deserved a discount. At first he said he wouldn't do it ("I'm not authorized to do that") but he eventually came through with 25 percent off. He did not say "thank you" when the transaction was completed; he stared at me like I was the customer from hell. Maybe to him I was.

I did not get the impression that he took my concerns seriously. I believe that a really well-run restaurant that cares about its customers, that wants to survive, that wants to prosper, that wants to become great rather than continue forever as a hole-in-the-wall on Divisadero, would train its staff like crazy about every possible problem and issue, including MSG, which is one of the most long-standing, significant health issues confronted by Asian restaurants today, with enormous liability issues attached to it. By this criteria, My Father's Kitchen does not seem to me to be a well-run restaurant.

By the way, regarding liability issues, the staff of My Father's Restaurant would be smart to familiarize itself with the San Francisco Examiner issue of February 28, 2013, the column by attorney Christopher B. Dolan, "Foodborne Allergens, Harm, Could Be the Cause for a Lawsuit." I would especially refer them to paragraph 2 where the writer describes a lawsuit titled Livingston vs. Marie Callendar's. This case involved MSG. Marie Callendar's wrote a very big check to Livingston.
author: R. F.

description:
Much better places on Clement.  Went during lunch and wasn't that busy but the waiters/ staff decided to seat us in the very corner towards the back while other tables for 3 were open.  I must say that the table layout is HORRIBLE in this place.  You can barely fit though some of the tables.  To get to my seat, i had to squeeze between a space roughly 6 inches (sparingly) between two tablest.  I'm not a big guy but it was still difficult getting to my destination.  One it's a fire hazard and two Would the workers like to eat in a restaurant they had to tip toe just to squeeze to their seat?. I even accidentally knocked over the fish sauce on the adjacent table.  And it was not just me having issues with getting to my seat.  Three women who were having lunch had the same issue who were seated right next to us a few minutes after.  

Food was alright, but big minuses on the price and the service.  We got our drinks but not once during our entire hour meal were we offered more water.  The only time we were asked how our meal was was towards the end when a friend signaled a worker to get a togo container.  The price for a Vermicelli bowl is ridiculous, 11 dollars without an eggroll, just the meat, noodles and greens.  You can easily get something 4 dollars cheaper in the inner richmond with more food.  Price is not a huge issue but if I'm going to be paying more for an "upscale" vietnamese restaurant the least I could have is someone checking in to give me some water.  I'm assuming that they must have the same difficulty getting to our seats as I did during our meal.  Will not be going back nor recommending.
author: D n.

description:
This is across the street from my doctor's office, so I thought I'd try it after an appointment one day. I'd never had Vietnamese food, but the Ga Satay looked really good. It is fantastic!! I went back after my next two doctor's visits, and then I ended up moving. I miss it.

The food is great, the service speedy (and they leave you alone to eat). The restaurant is big for San Francisco standards, I felt like I could eat without sitting back to back with a stranger, and I couldn't hear the kitchen. I ordered Coke but I also got water, and it had lemon juice in it - a nice touch. I highly recommend My Father's Kitchen!
author: Danielle D.

description:
This review is mostly for the pho. The five stars goes to the clean tasting, delicious, pure chicken broth. Honestly, the broth alone should win an award. The chicken pho and mixed chicken and beef pho use the chicken broth, but the beef pho uses beef broth.

I read some of the reviews prior to reading this, and feel the need to respond:
 
First, I am completely baffled by the complaints of "bland." What do you think chicken broth is supposed to taste like? I don't know what you're used to, but this is the pure stuff -- home made, no chemicals, MSG, etc. 

Second, I, too, was initially confused by the lack of sprouts, mint, etc., but I learned (by asking) that the family is northern Vietnamese, and this simpler version is their tradition. The family is very conscious of keeping to their traditions. (I know this, because my friend asked if they could change the menu to include vegetables in the pho, and they apologized, but said they felt very strongly about keeping to their cultural roots.)

Third, the last thing this place impresses me as is "trendy." Just because the front of house doesn't consist of non-English speaking immigrants, doesn't make it trendy, folks! They are just nice people, who try to get to know their regulars, and are staffing a restaurant as best they know how. 

Final comments -- this is inexpensive, simple and delicious. I usually only order the pho, but on the rare occasions I've ordered other things, I thought they were good. And yes, the peanut sauce is terrific. However, I would only go out of my way for the pho! 

The only negatives are that the tables and chairs are too dark for the small space, and the chairs are too small for anyone over 5'9".
author: Paul A.

description: Had a perfect lunch here on Saturday. It was rainy out so pho was the obvious/perfect choice. The actual pho was not the best I have ever had but the people that work there are so sweet they make the atmosphere awesome. The fried rolls were perfection! Had delicious Vietnamese coffee and Lagunitas! My friend and I had delicious lunch, beers and coffee for under $30--amazing. I will be back for sure!
author: Hallie W.

description:
dude, this place is WHACK - bring your vietnamese dad here only if you want to offend the shit out his elderly asian sensibilities.  

i've never felt compelled to pour salt into my pho before (yeah, think on that for just a second) - try as i might, i still wasn't able to entice any flavor out of the sad broth, even after also adding the lemon, sriracha, jalapenos and fish sauce available to me.  the noodles are thick and flavorless, further contributing to the blandness of the soup.  lastly, their "large" is the size of most smalls in other restaurants - i'm still hungry as i write this review.  

the real kick in the teeth was their "vietnamese iced coffee" which they westernize by using a higher ratio of coffee (highly diluted) to condensed milk (which you get only a small sliver of at the bottom).  when the drip finished in less than 5 minutes, i knew something was wrong.  i was able to force down about half of that watery abomination before pushing it away in disgust.

the sad reality is that this place will continue to do well, as they've smartly engineered themselves to cater perfectly to a lower pac heights clientele that doesn't know any better: fantastic location + fashionable blue bottle coffee drips right in front + predominately young/hipster waitstaff + deliciously misleading name and tagline.
author: Roberto M.

description: Great pho. Bad service still but I understand the lunch rush. It's hard to give really good service at lunch but then again, the higher price should also dictate better service.
author: Lulu M.

description:
I ordered the pork and meatball bun. The flavors were there. Maybe this would be better as a takeout item?  

I was there late on a Saturday alone. The staff wasn't busy and was staring at me while I ate which made it kind of uncomfortable to eat there.

I was really sad that they only had 12 food items on their menu.  I was also disappointed that the bun didn't come in a bowl.  Kind of hard to mix everything up on a plate...

Don't think I will be heading back to dine in. I will try takeout.
author: Laura Z.

description:
parking is very difficult around this area.

one thing about vietnamese food is that the best thing there is usually theyr pho.

In this case its true, its their pho.  The rest of their dishes are nice and clean tasting like their pho..BUT they are just that.  Clean and you can get that anywhere.  

They only have 2 rice dishes, both chicken...what about those who love pork?  lol.  They have a pork meatball and sliced pork dish which looks and tastes awesome, with some vermicelli noodles, but i'd rather have it over rice.

Prices are okay but for 7.50 for a rice dish, i'd want a little bit more.  Just saying a little more would make it 4 stars for me.
author: Bing D.

description:
Wow! the best pho place I've tried so far in San Francisco (or ever?).  Not only was the pho broth well layered, authentic, and slow cooked - but I'd have to say the place exudes an atmosphere of quality.  From the coffee to the pho to the satay, everything was inexpensive, tasty, and well-plated.  Definitely check this place out!

Update: I just have to say, this place is way better than Turtle Tower in the Little Saigon part of SF.
author: Adrian T.

description:
Looking for something warm and filling to eat immediately after I'd emerged from outpatient surgery nearby, my girlfriend suggested we try this small restaurant with "Vietnamese comfort food" as its tagline. Sounded perfect, so we went in.

The atmosphere was nice enough--cozy without being overly cramped (although I can imagine it could get that way with a bigger crowd)--with good natural light coming in from the windows facing Divisadero St. We were seated and given menus promptly, which was consistent with the overall good service. The food itself was another story.

First, the fresh vegetarian spring roll appetizer was both tasteless almost to the point of being non-existent, and wildly overpriced for what you get. There was almost none of the mint or cilantro that gives good rolls their zing, and instead of the fresh, firm tofu strips that are standard in most places, we found deep-fried strips that only accentuated the lack of flavor. Moreover, the dipping sauce was overly sweet and cloying. It's okay to try something other than a standard peanut-based sauce, but if you do, it should be something equally savory designed to pick up the other flavors of the spring roll, not hide the fact that there's no flavor to begin with.

We both ordered chicken pho as our main course, and it was more of the same issue with blandness--and something worse. The first thing we noticed in the broth was an undertone of pork flavor, an indication that the pots used to cook the broth for the different phos were being used interchangeably, a major culinary faux pas. Then we realized that we hadn't been given a plate of the usual accompaniments: basil, cilantro, bean sprouts, and fresh jalapeño peppers. When we asked about it, our server said they didn't offer those items except for the peppers. However, if we'd like, they could give us some mint, a small plate of which we gladly accepted. That helped give the soup a bit more flavor (and conceal the pork scent), but imagine our chagrined surprise when our check arrived...with a separate two-dollar charge for the mint!

A lot of folks are going to be fine with this quality of Vietnamese food; the rest of us will stick to known better places next time around.
author: Bill B.

description: Bland watered down version of Vietnamese food for untravelled palate.  Where is all the good stuff in the pho?
author: M S.

description: I just ate here for the first time yesterday, and it was awesome. Sure, it's tiny and crowded, but that's the nature of restaurants in SF, so no biggie. I had the fresh spring rolls, the ga satay, and an iced Vietnamese coffee - all were excellent. I'm already craving the ga satay again today! The service was really quick, which was important, since I only had about an hour to get in and out. The only room for improvement that I could see would be a couple more fresh (not fried) small plates, but I understand their desire to keep the menu small. All-in-all, I would recommend this place!
author: Julia L.

description: Hmm, never go for lunch at noon. Probably best to go after 1:30pm. Really no place to stand when waiting for a table and the hostess suggested we have a seat in the hallway of the restaurant, which was 3 chairs up against the wall which faced directly in front of tables with people eating their lunch, which was quite awkward to say the least. The wait was about 15 minutes and then we were lead to a 2 seat table that was in between 2 other parties having lunch. So in order for me to get to my seat the woman sitting at the table next to me needed to stop eating her lunch and get out of her seat to let me into my seat! ummm.... yeah HELL NO! I haven't even eaten yet and it has been an ordeal! So, lets fast forward to the food...... My chicken Pho came to the table looked appetizing and it was tasty, I feel I have had better. The one thing I couldn't stand was the couple sitting next to me ( so close I might add) their hot water from their Pho dishes were splatting on my bare skin when they were sipping their noodle dishes! ummm yeah double HELL NO! Over all not a good experience here at all!
author: Charmaine T.

description: I went here the other day while walking in the neighborhood the other day.  My wife always says that Vietnamese food is "comfort food" and I must agree.  I ordered a simple dish of spring rolls with a side of Blue Bottle coffee.  The rolls were fresh and tasty but the sauce was to be desired.  It tasted very weird and I just ate the rolls without it.  The coffee was ofcourse outstanding and I would definitly go back.  The service was excellent and found the conversation with the staff to be very informative and friendly.
author: Dan Z.

description: My "father's" kitchen? Maybe her father isn't Vietnamese.  I wanted to like this place. Clean place in location where good Asian food is lacking.  Pho tasted like just noodles in boiled water.  Northern style or not, still very bland that even hoisin couldn't save it.  Satay sauce on the grilled chicken rice dish was good but I've never seen such small strips of chicken.  "Comfort food" usually implies a decent satisfying amount.  Maybe order 2 or these dishes??
author: Jenny W.

description: This place is cute, hidden among the myriad of medical office buildings and locksmiths. I ordered the chicken pho, he ordered the beef. Beef surpassed in the flavor department by far. With the addition of all supplied garnishes, I still felt the dish was lacking in a depth of flavor... Still searching for the perfect bowl.
author: Stephanie V.

description:
I eat here about every 3 weeks b/c it's right near work and I like Vietnamese food.  I agree with many of the other reviews that this is different than other Pho spots and might be 'American' or 'White' Vietnamese food.  But to be honest, I dig the food.  A lot. 
It's a bit pricey but so are tons of other spots in SF.  It's still not too expensive and enjoyable.
What I can't get over is the dude with the long hair that seems to run the place.  He's consistantly rude, always behind (even when I call in orders 20 min in advance, and leaves me feeling like 'I'm never coming back to this place'.  
I've never written a Yelp review before and this experience inspired me to share my thoughts.  I praise the food (above), but I'm NOT going back!
author: Bruce S.

description: This place is clean, service good and food is nothing to complain about.  The menu is limited in comparison to typical vietnamese restaurants.
author: Dustin W.

description: The place was nice and clean, but I have to agree with Martin C's review of this place. The noodle was unusual and it didn't have a bite, and they varied in length. The broth was very bland and tasteless, it lacked finesse. A large size pho beef special for $10 + tip is overpriced. The Siracha Sauce saved the day, seriuosly!
author: Jaime L.

description: Having read the reviews I expected overpriced Vietnamese food.  However, the reviewer who noted the pho was bland was spot on.  The restaurant looks nice and service is friendly.  Just wished the food matched up.  I got the chicken pho and my hubby tried the roast chicken rice plate.  We started with the imperial rolls and they were tasty.  Entrees were underwhelming.  I expected the portions to be small, but the pho soup almost tasted watered down.  The flat noodles are to my liking.  But it came with very little else beyond a couple of strips of white meat chicken.  Hubby's roast chick plate was small and as he put it "nothing special".  There are 100's of better Vietnamese places.  This father's kitchen needs a mother's touch.
author: I have something to say... A.

description: I really like the rice and noodle plates here. Prices a little higher than most Vietnamese spots but dishes are fresh and classic. Small menu but everything is tasty and well prepared. Convenient location for this neighborhood that needed something good. Well done.
author: Brittany T.

description: I'm always happy with the food, but seeing as it is the only place to get Pho in this neighborhood, I REALLY wish it would stay open later!!  I never get home in time to go there for dinner...and it's closed Sunday!  A lot of people go out for dinner on Sunday...just sayin.'
author: Dani C.

description: The food  is alright but service is really outstanding. Our kid tossed his bow of soup on the table and caused a huge mess. The attendants helped all the way move to a different able. He was also nice enough to make a new bow of our kid. Highly recommend the place.
author: Abbie T.

description:
for a brand new restaurant, they're doing pretty well and offering some good cuisine right from the get-go.  obviously yes, with time will come the experience they need to transform this into a solid lunch venue, but they're well on their way.  

this pho, apparently being northern style, isn't quite the pho i'd normally devour at 3am or on lazy weekend mornings, as it tasted a bit "classier" to me.  though maybe that was the pristine looking wide/flat noodles and the lack of accoutrements aside from a single lemon wedge and a couple jalapeno slices that convinced me this was a chic restaurant serving an upscale version of pho.  

Tasty, but the flavor didn't quite win me over completely, hence the need for lots of sriracha.  the crispy imperial rolls appetizer, however, was delicious and packed the flavor punch i desired.

For the price (tax included in the menu price? how convenient for bill splitting!) and the atmosphere, I'd be inclined to come back.  Especially if we keep getting this sporadic rain, I gotta get my cold-weather pho fix before jacket season turns into sweater season.
author: Anne Marie B.

description: I came here after a UCSF appt duing "off lunch" hours. It's not an authentic "pho" place. Actually, it's just a noodle place. No spouts, tendons, tripe, etc in their soups. The soups are set with the flat rice noodles. Small selection but ok. Portion is smaller than what you get from a pho place. I had to order an appetizer plus bowl of soup to fill. This little restaurant clientele isn't Asians, hence, none of those authentic pho fixings. But it's a great place to have a little bowl of hot soup, right across from UCSF.
author: Tiffany W.

description: Someone else already said it, but their pho is rather bland. They substitute lemon for lime, and don't provide any basil or bean sprouts. Sadly, my noodles were also overcooked. When I ordered pho ga the waitress repeated it back to me like she was correcting me, which (though I hate to admit it) kind of annoyed me. One redeeming thing is that when I requested extra lemon, the waitress didn't seem bothered. Objectively speaking, the service was prompt and sufficiently friendly. The pho, however, was subpar.
author: Gema O.

description: This spot is great for some tasty Vietnamese food. The ingredients always seem fresh and their ice tea is delicious! It does close a bit early in the evening and the takeout service is quick.
author: Tyler S.

description: Saw a review for this new restaurant in The San Francisco Magazine a couple months back. I was ecstatic to hear more blue bottle coffee near my apartment and the possibility of delicious pho. The coffee was/is good, but I was a little disappointed with the pho. To me pho is really dependent on the broth, but the broth was kind "ehhh". The spring rolls were fresh and crispy. I especially liked the dipping sauce. It's pricey but all the portions were generous. I wish I had tried their other entrees besides pho. Service was friendly although I left feeling let down. I really wanted to fall in love and left feeling let down.
author: Jacqueline S.

description: I wandered in here for lunch after an appointment at UCSF Mt Zion, and I was pleasantly surprised by this new place. Nice atmosphere, very nice and attentive staff, and really delicious, flavorful North Vietnamese-style pho. OH! and eminently reasonable prices. Will definitely come back.
author: amanda a.

description:
i'm giving them 3.5 stars. on a tuesday a little after noon, they were packed with people who obviously worked in the surrounding hospitals. the space is small and quite limited so i had to share a table with another woman, which i didn't mind so much.

 the springrolls i got were fresh as far as the internal ingredients, however i could tell that they put them together in the morning and let them sit until someone orders them. the two ends were visibly and texturally dried out from being made earlier in the day. 

the noodles they use for their pho are more like flat noodles. the beef they use didn't get overcooked while sitting in the broth. it remained tender until the last spoonful. the dissappointing part was the broth. it was pretty damn bland. i may as well have been eating the noodles with salted water. 

the assortment of pastries they have at the front is confusing, but look delicious. the almond croissant was really one of the best almond croissants i've ever had. 

i'll return in hopes that they up their broth game.
author: Regina C.

description:
I had the beef pho and a ice tea.
beef pho - 2 stars
ice tea - 3 stars

The broth for the pho was really lacking flavor. the noodles were a little soft for my taste also. the meat was tender but other than the meat there was much else I liked about it. I'm used to getting lots of topping choices on a side plate but all i got was a lime - no leaves, sprouts, or anything else...

maybe this restaurant favors the ultra light flavor side of the scale because that's pretty much what the iced tea was like but I prefer my teas that way so I enjoyed it. not too sweet.

overall though, it wasn't good enough for me to want to come again. sorry.
author: S T.

description: Its clean, you wont gag by looking in the bathroom, the broth is more palatable than tea, but there is much better Pho in SF.  This a great starter Pho place for those bringing relatives in from Muncie or Little Rock, but this places does not rock.  Overall bland, but clean.
author: Mickey D.

description:
i only give five-star reviews...good karma and all. where that awesome karmic power may be faltering is in my delay to write this review. i've been meaning to for a year, ever since my husband and heard about and tried this truly authentic and delicious spot. we are both crazy for the pho, which is almost exactly how i remember it in vietnam with clean, subtle flavors. the imperial rolls and bun cha are also spot on. we are now really happy regulars.

to top it off, they have a nice story: after coming here in the 70's the father always dreamed of running a restaurant, now that he's retired, that dream has come to fruition. good luck and thanks for the lovely food!
author: Elizabeth M.

description: i am huge on customer service and they were incredible!. my 2yrld daughter and i went to have lunch there a few weeks ago. it's a small little place but the seating works out just fine. they made sure my daughter and i were good on our drinks, napkins and that our food was right. they also have wine which i don't see that at many vietnamese restaurants which was great! the food was delicious. i really enjoyed the spring rolls. when you pay they have tasty cookies you can help yourself with and some candy, my daughter enjoyed that a lot.
author: Rebekah S.

description: Tucked within a block full of deli's, corner stores, and medical offices, is a nice little spot called "My Father's Kitchen." It definitely draws you in to look closer. No burgers, philly cheese steaks, and wraps here. It's Ph! The selection is minimal and easy especially for those who may be new with Vietnamese cuisine. For my 1st visit, I started with  ch giò - crispy imperial rolls. Then I had the bún ch tht nng (aka No. 11)- marinated grilled pork and meatballs served with fresh herbs, rice vermicelli, and fish sauce. I truly enjoyed it. For those who live or work in the area, you might appreciate the quiet and minimalistic ambiance. On the next trip, I have to try their ph, which I hear is northern style- simple with less ingredients.
author: Leroid D.

description:
About a year ago my fiance introduced me to Pho and I've been hooked since.  She only took me to her go to places in LA so I was pretty spoiled only getting the best of the best without knowing it.  Moving up to SF I realized pretty quickly that it's not easy to perfect pho, as we were pretty disappointed with the places we had tried. 

My Father's kitchen seems to have broken that trend effortlessly bringing an authentic pho restaurant to San Francisco.  Everything is very fresh brought in daily and tastes incredible.  I would recommend this place to anyone wanting an authentic vietnamese pho. 

It also doesn't hurt that the owners are true gems!
author: Peter F.

description: TAKEOUT ONLY (does not include review of pho):  Missing places like this is what happens when you always walk the same route around the hood... Got some delish and reasonably priced takeout from here today for lunch.  SInce it was too hot for pho, and since pho likely won't take out well, we ordered five spice chicken rice (delish) and the vermicelli with pork and meatballs (perfect balance, came with fresh mint, basil and cilantro sprigs).  And the green papaya salad (decent, fresh) and the crispy imperial rolls (again delish).  So glad to have a less pretentious (than Out the DOor) place to get solid vietnamese food in the hood.  Will have to try the pho next time, though my love for Turtle Tower may win despite best efforts at proximity.
author: Isabel M.

description: This place is solid.  I've had Vietnamese food, but I am by no means an expert.  Nonetheless, very clean, food is very fresh, super tasty and comes in large portions.  The spring rolls are huge.  Would definitely recommend this spot and will eat here again!
author: Brian B.

description:
what you'll find at my father's kitchen:
traditional and simple menu (with a bonus of blue bottle coffee!)
very flavorful pho
sriracha on the table, yay!
really friendly wonderful people, family owned/run 
clean
nice simple design
will definitely stop back soon for another hot bowl of soup!
author: Olivia R.

description: One of the least enjoyable pho soups I have ever had.  The noodles were soft ribbon style (they said from n. vietnam, but I didnt see those when I was there).  The broth had too little flavor and they don't provide the sides to add flavor (also n. vietnam style).  I think I know why I didnt find this soup in N. Vietnam... it's just not as good as southern.
author: Adam B.

description: So happy to find an alternative to Out The Door for crispy veg imperial rolls with all the fixings. Place is super sweet, comfortable and simple, but done well. Great place to have an impromptu dinner on the way home from work.
author: Christine O.

description:
best place to get soup when it's cold out there!
Menu is really small, but it didn't bother me. chicken pho was simple, but flavorful and made with real chicken, not that rubbery stuff you find in other asian soups!
waitress girl was all alone, but totally on top of things and friendly.
author: anett r.

description: I like this place.  I'm not a pho expert by any means, but have tried a fair amount around the City.  They keep the menu simple with the pho and a handful of other dishes.  The pho is tasty, the service friendly, and usually efficient during the busy lunch hours.
author: Bill P.

description: YUM!  This is by no means that "authentic" to me, but it tastes freaking good.  Contemporary twist on classic Vietnamese dishes.  We had the beef/chicken pho and fried rolls.  They were delicious.  We'll definitely be back.
author: Matt S.

description: YUM!  the broth is so very clean and so NOT greasy...better than Turtle Tower, of which I am a fan.  Started with imperial rolls...tasty.  we then had the beef brisket pho and five spice chicken rice.  I'll definitely be making it back here.  The downside...they're not open on Sundays.  WAH.
author: Sonia C.

description:
Met a friend for lunch, on the early side (wary of the UCSF crowd mentioned by other Yelpers).

On the plus side, we got a table right away and the staff was super friendly. On the minus side, though, the place was soon crammed full of hospital lunchers & the tag team approach to table service was v-e-r-y, v-e-r-y  s-l-o-w.

We ordered:
1) Crispy Imperial Rolls - Ended up being the best part of the meal, once they finally arrived
2) Chicken Pho - Tasty, especially the chicken bits, but nothing special -- and we did not get ANY toppings

Overall assessment: Solid lunch spot, if you have plenty of time. Friendly neighborhood joint.
author: E. C.

description: My partner's been eating here 3 days a week for the past month.  I tried it yesterday, and it DOES live up to the hype!  Basic, flavorful broths and quality ingredients.  Very nice, friendly staff.   Thanks, "Erik-with-a-K"
author: Eric W.

description: Very healthy and lite. I felt good after eating it. It was no meal to remember, but i liked the simplicity of it all and also the cleanliness of the joint.
author: S. G.

description: Good, solid, and simple. Great staff. I eat here about once a week for lunch and I am never disappointed.
author: Christopher S.

description: My husband and I both had colds and had driven all the way from the East Bay to see our doctor. Afterwards we noticed this new, little restaurant and gave it a try. This was the best Pho I've ever had. Maybe it was because we were both craving something warm, salty, and comforting but it was honestly the only bowl of Pho I've ever been able to finish! Other reviewers didn't like the wide rice noodles but I found them cooked to perfection! They weren't gummy, or stiff, they were absolutely perfect. I agree it would have been nice to have the extra toppings (especially since I don't like chilies on mine) but when it comes to broth, and delicious, lean meat, this place was top drawer!
author: Mondrian M.

description: Excellent food and service. We had a tofu pho and vermicelli noodles and roasted pork. Delicious!
author: Ruchi A.

description:
I went here for lunch with my parents because they live in the neighborhood and we wanted to try the new restaurant out. We thought the food was okay. 

The goi cuon was pretty tasty. I've been to other Pho restaurants where the spring roll was tasteless, so I was pleasantly surprised by theirs. 
I ordered the Pho bo tai nam. I was surprised by the wider rice noodle, but I really liked it in the broth, which was flavorful enough not to need any sriracha sauce. However, I didn't like that the meat didn't come on the side so the beef was over cooked. I also didn't really like that no vegetables were served with it. 
My mom ordered the chicken satay over rice, and she says that it was pretty tasty, except she felt the peanut sauce that accompanied the dish was too spicy. 
My dad ordered the five-spice chicken, and was a little disappointed that it didn't have enough of the five-spice flavor that he's used to. In fact, he ended up dipping his chicken into my mom's peanut sauce! 

All in all, the atmosphere and service were pretty good, but I'm not sure I'd go back to eat there unless I was stranded at my parents' house and was really, really craving Pho.
author: Andrea W.

description: Why do I continue to be a sucker for a nice-looking little place with a cute name like this? Honestly it was the blandest Vietnamese food I've ever had! The spring rolls came with a peanut sauce that had absolutely no flavor -- even after liberally mixing Sriracha into the bowl. Chicken in satay? Nothing. Papaya salad? Nothing. This place would be perfect for parents with little kids who will only eat lukewarm noodles. And not cheap either!
author: Cathy M.

description: Well normally I would not write a review on a place that I haven't either gone to at least twice or that I haven't had multiple items from their menu. I am making the exception here because I will not be going back. I ordered the bun cha nem cua (imperial roll vermicelli). Although I more frequently tend to steer away from pork items, I ventured out anyway, and the rolls were actually pretty good. The remainder of the bun lacked in the area of vegetation. It was a lot less than I became accustomed to from places like PPQ. All-in-All, this place would have merited four stars if ,for one, they were not so expensive and two if they were to add more veggies to the bun. All I received was green leaf lettuce (33% of the dish), a sprig of cilantro, & a few (as in three) mint leaves. It was more like a lettuce salad with vermicelli and three Imperial rolls. Well there are no Vietnamese restaurants within walking distance around this area, so I guess the next time I am craving for Pho or Bun I will just have to travel out of the area.
author: An Marie M.

description: My Fathers Kitchen, what can I say except TOTAL FAIL on the PHO!!!!! me and a coworker were starving one day and since we work close to this place we decided to get some pho, bad choice for us... the soup was bland bland bland and where were the usual condiments, no siracha sauce or any of the usual suspects, only gave us a couple of jalapenos and some bean sprouts I was surprised because on the the sign out front it says VIETNAMESE comfort food totally not true, anyway Campbell's chicken noodle is better sorry guys but this place sucked bad .... never going back .. wait one good thing to say ... they do serve blue bottle coffee, but even that wont bring me back through those doors
author: Michael G.

description: This place was so endearing. A lot of it probably had to do with the name of the restaurant and the totally sweet head waitress (who also seemed like the owner), whose parents were cooking all the food. Family businesses rule and I 'm happy to support them. They only do lunch so the menu was simple. NOTE: THEY SELL BLUE BOTTLE COFFEE. That means instant points in my book. I had them assemble vegetarian pho (although still with beef broth) and I also tried their green papaya salad. All of it was very fresh tasting. The beef broth was subtle and comforting, and the noodles (a little thicker than I'm used to) were amazing and so tender. I felt like I could eat them all day! They put fried tofu and onions and tons of herbs in my pho, which was alright by me. The waitress said they didn't have vegetables in house, which was confusing to me, but it didn't bother me one bit. We came right before closing time so we were in and out of there pretty quickly, but it was by no means rushed. The place was clean and I really hope it does well in spite of it's somewhat odd location. The waitress also told me that they'd been getting requests for vegetarian pho and that her mother was going to try and develop a mushroom broth for us veggies. I want to come back and try their vermicelli bowls!
author: Laura M.

description: 3.5 stars. came here on a weekday, 4pm, to go order.  i hesitated b/c of mixed reviews.  so i called up my trusty sis and asked what to get. she mentioned 5 spice chicken but warned that it ain't a lot of food.  right she was--two flattened pieces w/rice. flavorful but not OMG TDF.  also go tthe shrimp spring rolls, which were just ok (and oddly long...10 inches?). given the off hour, my order was ready in just 7 minutes. i didn't eat until about 25 min later and the food help up ok. spring rolls--I think they need more cilantro.  All in all, ok for take-out.  Next time I'd skip the rolls. Oh, nice touch is that the put a little container of sirrachia in your to-go bag.  Sirrachia makes EVERYTHING taste better to me.
author: Caroline I.

description: had the pho ga for takeout. it was delicious! our order was ready so quickly!! Although I was only in there briefly, the decor looked nice and very comfortable. I look forward to coming back to dine in. The guy working there was awesome!  Great place!
author: Tia T.

description: Stopped in here today looking for comfort food after a very un-comforting doctors appointment.  it was very clean, unlike your typical vietnamese restaurant, but unfortunately, the pho could not compare.  The soup was bland, the meat was brisket was really dry, and no bean sprouts or mint leaves, They didn't even have hoisin sauce on the table.  I wanted to like it but it fell very short.
author: Kat Q.

description: tasty fresh food! wish they were open later than 7pm. hard to catch them for dinner. I have taken four groups of people there and they all LOVED it.
author: a w.

description: Sorry, I know 1 star is harsh but this place should be ashame of themselves. As somebody who was born in Los Angeles, raised in San Jose for over 30 years, I think I know authentic Pho/Vietnamese food when I see one. Of course this is San Francisco, I'm not on a mission to find one. It's almost like going to Del Taco to eat some good Hamburgers. But My Father's Kitchen, though, is the Chevy's of nammer's food. This establishment reminds me why I gave up on looking for good authentic Viet food in the first place. They don't even have hoison sauce on the table. Even if it's northern style, you still have all the other pointless condiments sitting there. I went here for lunch with some coworkers and they were so stoked to try a new Vietnamese restaurant that just opened on Divis. This is probably the first Vietnamese restaurant I've been to where there are no Asians working here. It's kind of like a lot of Latino-ran Japanese restaurants I see in San Bruno. I mean as long as the food is good, I don't mind who works here. Unfortunately, this place should be ashamed to be called Vietnamese food.... it should be Vietnamese-influenced dishes... definitely nothing close to comfort food as they claim. The Pho here uses some pretty thick noodles and the broth is not tasty at all. I don't think people realize how long you need to cook good broth without adding MSG to it. The Spring rolls are.... meh... I make it better at home. They got it right on the drip coffee. The ambience is decent, and it's very clean. But ya'll still didn't win me over. I would've put that extra star up there but when I have to go and ask for the bill.... then bring the payment to them, it shows they are not willing to compensate for the lack of authenticity. I have a new name for this place. It's My Father's Kitchen Where I Wasn't Allow to Go In So I Just Sat at The Dining Table To Eat.  I think that's more appropriate.
author: Anthony N.

description: The food here was tasty, but it was overpriced and the service was not good. When I order bun, I expect it to be, at the most, $8, but here it was $11. My boyfriend was not given chopsticks or a fork and I couldn't get anybody's attention, so he had to use my fork (I got both). This would have been forgivable, but they had to go through various checks when we went up to pay before finding the correct one because they were so disorganized. Although the food was above average, it was not worth it.
author: Hannah B.

description: Excited that a Vietnamese restaurant moved into my block. Reality is that it was the most tasteless Pho I've ever eaten. I have had better Pho at many hole in the wall places than at this newly redone cramped seating place. The prices and the quantity are a joke. The only thing gong for them is they serve Blue Bottle coffee. All my coworkers have tried it and none feel it's worthy of visit number 2.
author: sylvia k.

description: great lunch spot. pho and vietnamese coffee is delicious. the broth is clear and fresh tasting. he way the bun is served is odd to me, i'd like my lettuce cut up and ready instead of having to do it all myself. service is awesome.
author: Missy D.
